summary: In the passage, Paul Merson and Andros Townsend's ongoing feud is discussed, particularly focusing on Merson's criticism of Townsend's inclusion in the England national team. Merson initially doubted Townsend's abilities, but after Townsend scored a crucial goal for England against Italy, Merson admitted his mistake and praised the player. The passage also mentions recent events, such as Townsend's late appearance in a 0-0 draw between Tottenham and Burnley, and Merson's subsequent Twitter dig at Townsend, indicating that the conflict between the two continues.

Chelsea has made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. Muto, a Japan international, will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the move to Stamford Bridge is completed. The interest in Muto is not connected to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, would be the first Japanese player for Chelsea if he moves to London. He has earned 11 international caps for Japan, scoring once. A £4 million deal for Muto has been suggested, but he has not yet decided on joining Chelsea, stating it is an honor to receive the offer. Muto has continued to perform well, helping his club reach third place in the division with three goals in four games this season. Yokohama Rubber, Chelsea's new official shirt sponsor, has the largest tyre manufacturing in the world, and the sponsorship deal is the biggest in Chelsea's history.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers, potentially contributing to the obesity epidemic. The research compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with antibiotic prescription records, revealing that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by two years old. Children who took antibiotics as babies were particularly likely to be overweight, and repeated prescriptions before the age of two raised the odds of being a fat toddler. The study suggests that antibiotics may cause weight gain by killing gut bugs that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body, and possibly increasing appetite. The findings highlight the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of shocked tourists. The incident was caught on camera and showed the guard losing his footing, knocking his bearskin and dropping his rifle. He quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues continued to march. The guard was thought to have slipped due to metal protectors on his boots. The Changing of the Guard occurs daily in summer and every other day in winter, with two detachments for Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace under the command of the Captain of The Queen's Guard. Contrary to popular belief, these guards are fully operational soldiers, not just ceremonial.

The passage discusses the remake of the iconic miniseries "Roots" for a new audience. Originally aired in 1977, the series had over 100 million viewers and followed the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. A&E Networks, Lifetime, and History are collaborating to produce a new version of the miniseries, set to air in 2016, which will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The new series aims to be authentic by consulting scholars in African and African-American history. The updated "Roots" will be seen by a new generation that has experienced historical events and racial unrest, aiming to educate them on the importance of the story.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, alleges that in 1978, on his first day at Clarence House, he was forced into a situation involving an attempted orgy by palace aides. The incident left him in tears and he left the job the same day. After years of being haunted by the experience, and inspired by inquiries into alleged child sex abuse cover-ups by a VIP paedophile ring, Lawler contacted palace officials again last year. His complaints were reportedly ignored for months before the police were notified. The police are now investigating the claims, and a retired royal aide has been interviewed but denies involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate fully with any police probe.

In a creative and viral video, Oregon couple Jesse and Melissa Meek announced their pregnancy by rapping to the theme song of the '90s TV sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air. The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their life in Happy Valley, Oregon, and their decision to start a family. Inspired by the original song's storyline, the Meek's parody details their thoughts and experiences on becoming parents. The video concludes with the couple sharing a sonogram of their unborn child and expressing their surprise at the video's success. This unique approach to sharing the news of their pregnancy was also used by another couple in Pennsylvania last year, who recreated the show's title sequence for their announcement.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble was featured in key scenes and was part of a private collection of over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia owned by James Tumblin, who had collected items from the film since the 1960s. The auction also included other items worn by Leigh and co-star Clark Gable, such as a straw hat ($52,500) and Rhett Butler's trousers and jacket ($55,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 best-selling book, celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2014 and marked a significant moment in history when Hattie McDaniel became the first African-American actor to be nominated for and win an Academy Award for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child slipped and fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit, but was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises, with an injured leg, but was not attacked by the animals. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

In Handsworth, Birmingham, a speed camera aimed at a house on a residential road has been non-operational for over two years. The camera, part of the decommissioned fixed device system in the West Midlands since 2013, was rendered obsolete. Instead, speed enforcement is now managed by mobile camera units, motorway fixed cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the camera's unusual positioning and plans to address the issue, with no plans to include it in a new pilot project.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, is set to compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, according to the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt expressed his excitement and readiness to run, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to making the country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability for the event, anticipating "sprint magic" during the competition. The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed their commitment to Barcelona by attending a basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, which ended in an 85-80 victory for Barca in the Euro League. Despite the win, Real Madrid remained at the top of their Euro League division due to a points difference. Neymar recently played a key role in Brazil's 1-0 win against Chile in a challenging match at the Emirates Stadium. Before the international break, Barcelona, led by Luis Enrique, won their El Clasico match, placing them four points ahead at the top of La Liga. Neymar and his teammates will return to La Liga competition on Sunday, facing Celta Vigo in their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

In a span of four days, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants, with SOS calls received from 20 boats in distress. Save the Children fears 400 migrants could be missing due to a possible capsize of a ship carrying 550 people near the Libyan coast; however, the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. The International Organization for Migration reported over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy and 2,000 rescued at sea in the first quarter of 2015, with most migrants coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsene Wenger is unsure why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is glad he did, as Sanchez has made an instant impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Sanchez was courted by several elite clubs, and Wenger speculates Liverpool may have used their interest in him as leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities, efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, and also comments on Liverpool's impressive performance last season under Brendan Rodgers, who found solutions despite the sale of Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge. Wenger downplays speculation about a potential summer transfer move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, plans to attempt cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The hour record is a highly coveted achievement in cycling, with Wiggins aiming to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. Wiggins, who has three Olympic gold medals in track cycling, hopes to break the current hour record of 52.491 km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, and tickets will go on sale from April 19, with a capacity crowd of 6,000 expected to support Wiggins.

In the Fed Cup play-off, Serena Williams, a twice French Open champion, faced a tough challenge against Sara Errani but ultimately prevailed with a score of 4-6, 7-6 (3), 6-3, maintaining her career record of 8-0 against the Italian player. However, Williams expressed disappointment as the US team, including Alison Riske, lost the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in relegation to World Group II. Williams admitted she was not as ready for the claycourt season as she had thought, despite her recent Australian Open win. The US now faces a challenge to return to the elite nations in the competition, with US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasizing the need for hard work and improvement.

River Plate, an Argentine football club, is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them from 2001 to 2005. Falcao, 29, has had a challenging time at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals during his loan spell. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's openness to Falcao's return, stating that "the doors are open." Falcao has had a successful international career, recently equaling Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. During his time at River Plate, he scored 34 goals in 90 appearances. It remains uncertain whether Manchester United will retain Falcao or if he will return to his parent club, Monaco.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has become the official face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city background. The partnership was arranged by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertising campaign, including her single "Mirror Man." Ella expressed her excitement about working with the brand, and the CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, which manages her, stated the synergy between the artist and the brand is strong, anticipating an exciting 2015.

The passage discusses the shock and outrage experienced by the family and friends of Aaron Siler, a man shot dead by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, last month. A billboard featuring Officer Torres and his dog was erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanking the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and demand its removal, stating it feels like a celebration of the officer's actions. The police association claims no offense was intended and that the billboard was to express gratitude for community support. Aaron Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant when he was shot after a vehicle and foot pursuit. Officer Torres had previously shot 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives, 10 days before Siler's shooting. Both shootings are under investigation.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border, according to Iranian state media. The fighting occurred in the southeastern town of Negur, where Iranian forces also killed three militants. The militants were reported to have crossed into Iran from Pakistan. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack; it is an anti-Iranian group that has been active in Balochistan, a region on the border of southeastern Iran and Pakistan. The group has targeted both Shiites and Iranian interests in the past, including a deadly attack in 2013 that killed 14 Iranian border guards. Following the recent incident, Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving assailants. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and is actively investigating, while also asking Iranian authorities to share any evidence they have.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan's parliament regarding the presence of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) and extraterrestrial life. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that Japan's Air Self-Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered a UFO from outer space. The discussion was prompted by a query from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler-turned-lawmaker, who is known for his involvement in various fields, including politics, sports-entertainment, and humanitarian efforts. Inoki claims to have seen a UFO but is unsure if aliens exist. This exchange is not the first time Japanese politicians have debated the implications of extraterrestrial visitors, as in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal ramifications of defending against an outer space invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, eastern China's Anhui Province. Pai was squatting on the toilet, standing on the rim to avoid touching the seat, which then collapsed and shattered. He was found bleeding and was hospitalized, receiving dozens of stitches. The incident was believed to be an accident, and the passenger initially claimed he was sitting when the poorly built toilet gave way.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old Pennsylvania man from Limerick Township, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl and filming her, as well as other individuals, with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The abuse reportedly occurred over a four-year period. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the girl discovered the hidden camera in her home in March. Rebbie admitted to filming the victim and other juveniles, and the videos were captured over a three to four-year period. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is set for May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family remains unknown.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a unique series of father-daughter portraits where fathers leap into the air while their daughters look directly into the camera, smiling. This concept allows fathers, typically seen as serious, to showcase their fun side. The images are from Aoyama's latest book, "Daughter and Salary Man," and feature fathers in suits and daughters in casual clothing, posing in front of various Japanese landmarks. Despite some older fathers appearing slightly pained, the photographs have garnered significant interest online for their distinctive and curious nature.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and its relation to the county championship season. It focuses on Kevin Pietersen's emotional range during a Surrey team photo before the season's start, indicating a potentially sensational return to the England team. Pietersen's last international appearance was during the 2013-14 Ashes tour in Australia, where England suffered a whitewash series defeat. With the hope to regain the Ashes in 2015, Pietersen rejoins Surrey to attempt a return to the Test set-up, participating in team events and joking with teammates and photographers.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time. Initially fired due to poor performance, Ze Maria was reinstated by owner Angelo Massone but was sacked again after a loss to FC Botosani. The team now stands 16th, six points from safety, and will be coached by Serbian Vanya Radinovic. Ze Maria, who played for Inter Milan and Parma, had been Ceahlaul's third coach this season, replacing Florin Marin in January.

The passage discusses Radamel Falcao's struggle at Manchester United after his move from Monaco and his former teammate Nabil Dirar's opinion on the situation. Falcao, a former Atletico Madrid striker, faced difficulties in regaining his form after a serious knee injury. Despite United having the option to pay £46 million for a permanent transfer, they were unlikely to do so due to his limited success, scoring only four goals all season. Dirar believes Falcao might regret leaving Monaco, as he was unhappy there but could have played and participated in the Champions League with Manchester United. Dirar suggests that Falcao might have needed a more supportive atmosphere, implying that staying at Monaco could have been a better choice for him.

A robbery occurred at a Christchurch dairy when a tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask demanded cash from the owner's daughter, making off with the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The incident took place on Union St in east Christchurch at around 12:30 pm on a Saturday. Police were called to the scene but found no signs of weapons being used. The offender, captured on security footage, is still at large, and police are appealing to the public for help in identifying the suspect.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for having inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students. Initially arrested in March for an improper relationship and released on bail, she was arrested again after another student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado admitted to kissing one student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year. She was suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave. She posted a $50,000 bail after her second arrest but her plea on the second set of charges remains unknown.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming in a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times. The dog belonged to the local bike shop owner. The crocodile, which is part of a nearby sanctuary, held onto the dog for hours as it moved through the marina. Tourist Tim Weston witnessed the event and shared the video, which has garnered reactions of horror on social media. Despite the incident, crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta due to the mangroves in the area and their increasing proximity to human habitats as a result of urbanisation.

In the passage, Steve Bruce remains confident in Hull City's ability to avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which left them fighting to stay up. Initially aiming for 10 wins to secure survival, Bruce now hopes that nine or eight wins might be sufficient. Hull faces challenging upcoming fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries of key players, such as Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, and Nikica Jelavic. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory moved them to fifth in the table, but coach Ronald Koeman had to address an issue with Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty that was designated for James Ward-Prowse, highlighting the importance of team rules.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers, leading to the annulment of the entire school's results in 2014. The local education authority investigation found that some pupils altered their answers outside of exam conditions, and Guffick did the same. Although he claimed the changes were to make the answers more legible, the National College for Teaching and Leadership panel ruled that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, who has had limited playing time, enjoyed a sunny day with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri, and their son. The couple tied the knot in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius in 2014 after dating since 2012. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is active on Instagram, showcasing her modelling work. Lindegaard joined the Premier League in 2010 from Norwegian side Aalesunds but has only made 19 league appearances. Currently, he is the third-choice goalkeeper at Old Trafford, behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his limited success on the pitch, Lindegaard's personal life is flourishing.

At a Sotheby's auction, the glowing blue letters from above Yankee Stadium, expected to fetch $300,000 to $600,000, received no bids. The letters, owned by Reggie Jackson since 2008, had been atop the stadium since 1976. Jackson hoped to see a new generation enjoy the Yankees and New York City icon. Meanwhile, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

In the passage, Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addresses the professional responsibilities of Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after they were caught engaging in off-field activities that could negatively impact their image as professional athletes. Sterling and Ibe were seen inhaling nitrous oxide and using shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to them about their actions but decided not to discipline them, hoping to move past the incident. He emphasizes the importance of understanding the responsibilities that come with being a professional sportsperson. Additionally, Rodgers discusses the potential return of Steven Gerrard for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, but his main focus is on guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his leadership. He believes that experiencing close losses can be part of the learning process and improvement for the team.

Mesut Ozil, enjoying his home comforts in London, shared a picture of himself relaxing with his dog after Germany's 2-0 win over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. The Arsenal playmaker, who missed the Newcastle game due to illness, is set to play against Liverpool in the Premier League. Ozil, signed for £42.5 million from Real Madrid in 2013, has been in good form since recovering from injury, contributing four assists and scoring three goals since January. He claims to have adjusted well to English football, preferring the frequent matches and lack of winter break.

The passage discusses Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu's statement regarding the team's satisfaction with manager Luis Enrique. Despite speculation about a replacement, Bartomeu asserts that the club is'very happy' with Enrique, who has been in charge since last summer under a two-year deal. With only six games away from winning the title, Enrique's performance has impressed the president. Bartomeu emphasizes that there is still time to discuss Enrique's contract in the future, as the focus is currently on La Liga and potential victories in three trophies. The passage also highlights Barcelona's recent victory against Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson is set to sign a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay at the club until 2020. The agreement comes after discussions throughout the season, and Henderson is expected to earn around £100,000 per week. As the club's vice-captain, Henderson has been an integral player for Liverpool, contributing 13 assists and seven goals from midfield this season. His new contract makes him the third key player, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, to agree on a contract extension under Brendan Rodgers. Henderson is also expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling, who has rejected a new deal, are expected to resume in the summer.

Filipe Luis wishes to remain at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Signed in July, Luis has faced challenges securing the left back position at Stamford Bridge. Atletico Madrid hopes this situation may provide them leverage. Luis expressed his happiness at Chelsea and aims to stay until his contract expires. He recently played for Brazil in friendly matches against France and Chile. Now, his focus shifts to the Premier League title run-in, with Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizing focus and hard work for the upcoming challenging matches.

Nathan Hughes had his ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal. Initially suspended for three matches, the Wasps No 8 was found'reckless' for not preventing his knee from colliding with North's head. The ban was rescinded following fierce criticism, and Hughes is now free to return to action. North was advised to take a minimum of a month off due to concussion symptoms, marking the third time he had been knocked out in two months.

The passage describes how a series of dramatic, reddish sunsets in Washington were caused by wildfires in Siberia. The fires were initially started by farmers burning grass in their fields but grew out of control due to strong winds, eventually spreading throughout the region and destroying dozens of villages. The fires produced significant smoke, which was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, including parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunsets are a result of smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange hues to be more pronounced. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the red sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig's brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway a month after purchase. On April 1, she was informed that the car had been found and would be returned with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of getting upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the car thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. Despite the positive outlook, she is dealing with the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana in the car and creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant to honor Mick Sexton, the man who found her car and notified the police.

The passage discusses Manchester City's financial incentives tied to qualifying for the Champions League. Players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure have incentivised contracts, and they stand to lose £500,000 each if the team fails to qualify. Manchester City needs to finish in the top four of the Premier League to automatically qualify for the Champions League, as the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. The team's performance has dipped, and they are in a position where they might miss out on top players like Paul Pogba, who is also a target for rivals Manchester United.

In the'mini-derby', Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal from a free-kick. The match featured a high number of English players, including 10 Mancunian players. It was held at Altrincham's 6,000-capacity home, offering a more senior-like experience for the young players. Both sides displayed skill and commitment, suggesting promising futures for some of the participants. United now trails leaders Middlesbrough by two points in the cross-town clashes, while injury-hit City has lost both matches in the Under 18s Premier League play-off series.

In the passage, England goalkeeper Joe Hart praises Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' following Buffon's 147th international cap. Hart, who has represented his country 50 times, draws inspiration from Buffon's longevity and professionalism. Both goalkeepers are celebrated for their achievements, with Hart expressing his desire to continue adding to his international caps and aiming to learn from Buffon's example.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer burrito deliveries to customers' doors in 67 cities. The service will include a nine percent service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. Chipotle previously turned down offers from other delivery services but has now given Postmates the go-ahead. The Postmates app uses independent contractors for deliveries. Chipotle's success has attracted attention from presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, who have been spotted in Chipotle outlets. Other franchises, such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring or expanding their delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings in 2013, have publicly urged for the death penalty to be removed as a possible sentence for the convicted perpetrator, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In their opinion piece for The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard expressed the immense impact the tragedy had on their family, including the loss of their 8-year-old son and severe injuries to their daughter. They acknowledged the brutality of the crimes but sought a resolution that would avoid years of appeals and further pain for their family. The Richard family requested the Department of Justice to consider an alternative sentence of life imprisonment without the possibility of release and the waiving of appeal rights for Tsarnaev.

The passage describes the transformation of an enormous Boeing 747 jumbo jet into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing an estimated £400 million. Over a three-year period, the aircraft was customized to fit the owner's specifications, reducing its capacity from 600 passengers to accommodate just the tycoon and dozens of guests. The luxury plane features a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a lounge and'state room' at the back, and eight full beds in the 'aeroloft' on the top deck for sleeping. Additional amenities include a conference room, multiple lounges, and an onboard restaurant, making it one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) from Cape Canaveral, Florida. However, the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful as the rocket landed too hard for survival, tipping over. This was SpaceX's second attempt; the first in January ended with the rocket hitting the drone ship at an angle and exploding. SpaceX aims to reduce the cost of space access by reusing rockets like airplanes. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an ISSpresso machine, to the ISS and later return with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments and trash back to Earth. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, and the first successful launch following a scrubbed attempt on Monday due to weather conditions.

Priscilla Presley is set to witness the first wedding at Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, as part of a contest launched by NBC's Today show. The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will have their wedding at the chapel inside the Westgate Hotel on April 23. The package includes a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla emphasized that the event and chapel are "first-class" and not a joke, with the chapel being the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Elvis's Memphis home. Couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation to enter the contest.

In the Barclays Premier League, Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City, who are four points ahead. Both Henderson and Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet have played 47 games this season, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. After a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, Henderson thinks Liverpool can put pressure on City. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored goals in the match, contributing to the victory. Despite setbacks against Manchester United and Arsenal, Liverpool aims to keep winning and close the gap in the race for the Champions League.

Roma broke their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli 1-0 in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League positions. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute after a successful counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis played a key role by saving numerous shots from Napoli in the second half. The win temporarily moved Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches. Security was tight during the match due to past incidents between the teams, but no issues were reported.

In a lackluster season, Doncaster Rovers find themselves in mid-table mediocrity in League One. Their match against Fleetwood Town, with both teams having little to play for, resulted in a goalless draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. This left Doncaster's media team with the challenging task of compiling match highlights for their YouTube channel, resulting in a 27-second video featuring only 14 seconds of actual match action: kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

In the passage, Roland Giroux has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a type of fish. He forms this connection by removing two bullying fish from the tank and then interacts with his pet by feeding it and giving it massages. The blood parrot cichlid responds by becoming more sociable, enjoying being stroked, and engaging in daily play sessions with Giroux. This special relationship is captured on camera, showcasing the fish's reactions to touch and its attachment to its owner. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid fish, first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs, including a wrist injury he sustained from punching a locker. Stokes is known for his fiery character and has had clashes with players like Marlon Samuels. England's coach, Peter Moores, played a crucial role in guiding Stokes after their conversation following the Samuels incident. The passage emphasizes the importance of managing Stokes' aggressive nature while allowing his character to shine through. It suggests that although there may be lows along with highs, the team should not quash his natural exuberance. The potential inclusion of a second spinner, Adil Rashid, is mentioned, which could affect the places of Stokes or Chris Jordan in the team. England aims to help Stokes and other exciting players reach their full potential in international cricket.

The passage describes a highly anticipated Wales vs. Belgium Euro 2016 qualifier match set to take place on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, which has been declared a 33,000 sell-out. Both teams have 11 points from five games, with Belgium on top due to a superior goal difference. Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel has raised expectations of qualifying for the 2016 finals in France. The match's location at the Cardiff City Stadium is preferred by the Wales squad over the Millennium Stadium, and it is mentioned that UEFA rules prevent a change in venue within 120 days of the scheduled date.

The passage announces England coach John Peacock's selection for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, featuring a squad of young players from various Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. The team, defending champions from last year, has a 100% record in qualifying and is placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7, followed by games against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return to the squad after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers, and Arsenal's Chris Willock is called up for the first time.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent. He has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona but previously rejected Barcelona's La Masia offer to focus on his studies. City is in talks with Anderlecht's chairman for a compensation agreement, as Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort found strangled and beaten in a Fulham flat, south-west London, in March. The Mexican national worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. The arrested man has been bailed and is due for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing to anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan before her death to come forward. The investigation is ongoing, and police are not yet confirming whether her profession is central to the case.

Dawn, a woman who experienced seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to confront her long-term friend and convicted burglar Jamie about the theft of £207 meant for her babies' grave stone. After a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, Dawn was distraught and left the stage in tears. The money was intended for a £500 headstone for her child Daniel James, and Dawn felt betrayed by Jamie, whom she had trusted.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group, in northern Iraq, with most being women, children, ill, or elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders and involved Peshmerga forces who sent the freed Yazidis to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The Yazidis, of Kurdish descent with a pre-Islamic religious background, have faced persecution, particularly under ISIS' control, which led to a major humanitarian crisis. An international coalition, including the United States, responded with airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS in the region. Approximately 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, constituting less than 1% of the country's population.

In the 2014-15 season, Harry Kane, a young and dynamic striker for Tottenham, had an outstanding performance, which led to his inclusion in England's national team under Roy Hodgson. As a result of his remarkable season, Kane was nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. To celebrate his achievements, Copa90 produced an animated video featuring Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season. The video, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?" showcases his impressive performances, including goals against Chelsea and Arsenal, as well as his debut goal for England. The video was released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane was competing against players like Eden Hazard of Chelsea and Alexis Sanchez of Arsenal for the top prize.

In the passage, Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right person to lead Liverpool despite a season without trophies and likely missing the top four. Carragher believes one bad season shouldn't define a manager's future. He acknowledges the challenges Rodgers faced with new players not fully integrating and suggests focusing on next season for improvement. Carragher won a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, providing coaching in schools in deprived areas through his 23 Foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to it being deemed a security risk. The plastic gun, which fires sponge darts, was detected by X-ray machines and security officers requested James to hand it over. Airport security, described as 'over-zealous' by James's father, also conducted a thorough patting down and inspection of the child. The family was going to Lanzarote for a 10-day holiday over Easter. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to post the toy back to the family's home, stating that the safety and security of passengers is their first priority, and all regulations on security are set by the government. The prohibited list includes replica or model guns, and no items resembling prohibited items are allowed through security.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife who meets specific criteria. He offers accommodation, a possible company car, phone, and laptop to the successful candidate. The ideal partner must be a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good in the kitchen and bedroom, and enjoy the outdoors while also being a "princess when needed to be." The 31-year-old, named Rich, describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, a property owner, and financially successful. He promises to spend generously on his partner and considers all reasonable offers. Former partners are not eligible to apply.

The passage discusses Football Association chairman Greg Dyke's efforts to implement radical changes, including increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. Dyke faces opposition from the Premier League and wants to change the rules so that 'home-grown' means having trained in England for three years before the age of 18. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—support Dyke's proposals, warning that the English game will suffer if the proposals are blocked. They argue that the pool of English talent playing at the top level is shrinking, and the lack of opportunities for young talent is a clear disadvantage for the national team. The passage also mentions some promising young players, such as Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, who are breaking through into the top level.

In the upcoming episode, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, becomes the proud mother of the show's latest addition, a baby girl. Aidan Turner's character, Ross Poldark, gazes lovingly at his new daughter, showcasing his deep affection for Demelza. However, the pregnancy timeline in the show is rather unconvincing, as it jumps from the announcement of the pregnancy to Demelza being eight months along without any explanation of the passing time. The birth of the baby occurs just minutes later, with the last month of pregnancy seemingly passing in a blink of an eye. Fans have taken notice of the show's fast-paced pregnancy storyline, making comments on social media about the rapid progression of pregnancies in the show's timeline.

In the Barclays Premier League, Leicester's manager Nigel Pearson encourages his team to stay focused on their own games rather than worrying about their relegation rivals. Despite being bottom of the table, a recent 3-2 win at West Brom has provided a survival lifeline, with Jamie Vardy scoring an injury-time winner. Pearson believes that if Leicester manages a strong run-in, they can give themselves a realistic chance of Premier League survival, emphasizing the importance of doing their own job and avoiding overly optimistic outlooks.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, has set a new record for the longest migration of a mammal, swimming 14,000 miles from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. The journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, indicating her origin. This long-distance trip suggests that some western gray whales could be eastern grays, potentially lowering the estimated number of western gray whales to 150.

The passage describes an unexpected event on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, where 1,000 ft of seabed was forced to the surface overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula near the town of Rausu. This land emergence, rising as high as 50 ft from the sea surface in some places, is believed by geologists to be a result of a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater area into the air. The new landmass measures approximately 1,000-1,640 ft long, 100 ft wide, and has risen 30 to 50 ft above sea level. The sudden appearance of the land surprised locals, as there were no prior indications of the movement, such as sounds or tremors. Authorities do not expect the landslide to cause further expansion and believe this event is unrelated to earthquakes or the 7.8 magnitude earthquake that struck the Kathmandu Valley. The exposed seabed still has marine organisms, such as seaweed and sea urchins, attached to it.

Gregory van der Wiel has refuted rumors of his departure from Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped from a Champions League match against Chelsea, van der Wiel asserts his happiness and intention to sign a new contract. However, with the club being linked to Barcelona's Dani Alves, van der Wiel's position may be under threat.

Carlos Tevez, currently under contract with Juventus until the end of next season, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer for his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Boca's president, Daniel Angelici, has confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old, but Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Despite being the league's top scorer, Juventus has accepted his decision to leave and has started identifying potential replacements. Tevez has previously stated his intention to end his career at Boca Juniors, his first club. His international manager, Tata Martino, believes the move would not affect Tevez's Argentina future, emphasizing the importance of Tevez continuing to perform at his current level.

During an exciting 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, tore his left trouser leg, exposing his underwear. Despite this wardrobe malfunction, Bayern secured a spot in the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. Porto, who had a two-goal lead from their previous match, was overwhelmed by Bayern's performance, leaving European rivals wary of the Bundesliga giants' prowess.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2 km south of Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries ranging from chest and shoulder pains to abdominal pain and arm injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were the first to be flown to the Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or further assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, while two females were uninjured. The highway was closed off with diversions in place south of Fernvale. Emergency crews rescued one trapped individual, and patients were airlifted by Rescue 500 helicopter. The highway remained closed for a few hours.

The passage discusses an upcoming Premier League match between Arsenal and Chelsea, highlighting Arsenal player Mesut Ozil's excitement about his new Apple Watch. Ozil compares the watch to Michael Knight's watch from the show Knight Rider. The passage also mentions Arsenal's current position in the league, their upcoming match against league-toppers Chelsea, and the return of Jack Wilshere after a five-month injury. Club legend Ray Parlour expresses his belief in Wilshere's potential but raises concerns about his fitness record, drawing a comparison to fellow player Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford, despite sending off three players from both teams this season. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the match against Wales due to a red card in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Clattenburg has been accused of favoring United in the past but has only sent off two players from United this season. Both teams have contrasting forms heading into the derby, with United winning their last five league games and City struggling since the turn of the year. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string," believing he would quit after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to his criminal past. Katter, who has experienced racist attitudes himself, sympathized with Gordon's position. Gordon was forced to leave the Queensland Labor Party and announced he would remain in the parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the government. Katter's statement, which included the term "black puppet," sparked criticism and discussion on social media. He defended his choice of words, citing his personal experiences and the racial overtones in the government's treatment of Gordon. Katter used examples of other independents becoming government puppets but assured that Gordon would not follow the same path.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and stares, she creates videos to show that people with disabilities are not so different from everyone else. Her motivation is to change representation in media and encourage people to think before judging. Dayna has made several videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and now does motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City has expressed interest in Manchester United player Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. The move would be commercially appealing for the MLS side, which has a large Latin-American fanbase and is coached by Adrian Heath. Hernandez is also a target for eight European teams, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, with a potential sale price of around £8 million. Additionally, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from several European clubs if he does not agree to terms with United.

At a 76 Station in South Los Angeles, a gang of at least three people set a white Dodge Charger on fire by pouring gasoline on it and igniting it, following an argument with the driver. The incident occurred early Saturday morning around 12:15 am. Two passengers were inside the car during the attack, but no one was injured. The car's entire front end was destroyed. The driver's grandmother reported that the suspects attempted to carjack her grandson, but he managed to escape. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the case as an arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being utilized for the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from southern Iowa, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting to his misdeeds and pledged not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that any circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state. Despite his misconduct, Manuel has received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com, with a perfect five out of five stars in patient satisfaction ratings.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135 U reconnaissance plane in international airspace over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional" manner, according to the U.S. The Pentagon and State Department will file a complaint through diplomatic channels with Russia. The incident follows a similar encounter a year prior over the Sea of Okhotsk, which was also deemed dangerous. Russian and U.S. aircraft frequently encounter each other in Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot, specifically the Marriott Springhill Suites, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case and tied to a truck safe with padlocks and chains. The thief likely broke the car window, used a rope to pull the rifle case, and utilized the momentum from another vehicle to free the case from the lock. The theft also included the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. The rifle has not been recovered, and it is unclear if the thief specifically targeted the agent's car. The hotel is located near the city's airport and the state's FBI office, but lacks surveillance cameras. The Secret Service was notified of the theft but did not comment on any increased security measures during Obama's visit.

In July 2012, Luigi Costa, a 71-year-old man, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in the dining room of Freebody's home in Red Hill, Canberra. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa after the attack and found evidence of Costa's mental state declining before and during the incident. Costa's state of mind is crucial to the case, as a not guilty verdict can be returned if it's proven that he was suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the attack, rendering him unable to understand his actions or their consequences.

In a 1-0 win against Burnley at Goodison Park, Everton's Ross Barkley missed a penalty kick in the 10th minute, which was awarded for a foul by David Jones on Aaron Lennon. Barkley took the penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who has a 15 out of 16 success rate in the Premier League. Despite the miss, Everton won the match with a goal from Kevin Mirallas. Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision to take the penalty, stating he was happy to have multiple players capable of taking penalties and that Barkley showed responsibility by taking it. The match's outcome spared Barkley's mistake as it did not affect the final result.

Two passengers were found dead in a murder-suicide on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The incident occurred on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, which departed from Tampa, Florida, and was in San Juan, Puerto Rico at the time. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating. The cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has achieved a successful start in World Cup qualifying as the coach of Curacao. The team advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament, winning 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw in the second-leg match against Montserrat. Kluivert's coaching experience includes working with Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup. Curacao's next matches in the qualification process are against Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has previously experienced the World Cup as a player and as an assistant coach under Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, a renowned footballer with numerous European trophies, considers keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as significant as winning another trophy. Despite the team being at the bottom of the table with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic and committed to ensuring Leicester's survival. He has had a successful career, winning 15 trophies with Inter Milan and titles with River Plate and Real Madrid. Now, he views saving Leicester as a major objective and is considering staying beyond his current one-year deal, as he and his family are happy in the East Midlands.

23-year-old Gemma, a mother-of-two, is in danger of being banned from seeing her children due to her ongoing issues with alcohol, partying, and substance abuse. Her mother, Debbie, has been taking care of the children since they were four months old and is now threatening to ban Gemma from the children's lives. Debbie also suspects Gemma of stealing from them, including an alleged theft of an iPad. Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past. Social services had previously threatened to take the children away, leading Debbie to take responsibility for their upbringing. Now, Debbie plans to ban Gemma from her home and the children's lives due to her unreliability and destructive behavior.

In a match at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal, leading to a 1-0 lead against Manchester United. However, Sky Sports pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, argued during their half-time analysis that the play should have been stopped due to a foul in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry had executed a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, causing Falcao to fall. The pundits agreed that Terry's tackle was a foul, with Souness describing it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry expressing sympathy for Falcao as a fellow striker. Despite acknowledging Falcao could have been stronger to stay on his feet, the pundits collectively believed the challenge from Terry should not have gone unpunished.

The passage recounts an incident where Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway. Everyone on board was safely evacuated, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver. The fire was captured on video by Michael Barnett, who initially didn't know the bus belonged to the country band. The rear tire of the bus blew out, leading to the fire, which destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except Hillary Scott's Bible. The band's two other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time.

The passage discusses the potential use of space lasers for powering homes in the future, as proposed by Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University. These lasers would convert sunlight into energy, which would then be sent back to Earth. The technology could make solar power more viable, even in places like Scotland, and provide immediate power to disaster-stricken areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and the plan is to move to Portugal for further testing. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the possibility of the technology being used for weapons, although the lasers would not be powerful enough to cause significant harm. This concept is different from a proposed laser system for the International Space Station (ISS) to clear'space junk,' which also would not be weaponizable.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old predatory convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' for young girls, has gone on the run after escaping from a psychiatric unit. He was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, on Tuesday at 6.15 pm. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He is described as 5 ft 8 ins tall, heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard before leaving the hospital. Munden was previously convicted of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children and has been found with children's clothes, books, and dolls at his home. He suffers from autism, mild learning difficulties, and has difficulty controlling his sexual interest in small children. A manhunt has been launched to find Munden, as he is subject to a hospital order and his whereabouts are considered urgent due to his criminal history and learning difficulties.

In response to the question 'Provide a concise summary of the following passage, covering the core pieces of information described':

The passage discusses a legal dispute involving Donald Sterling, the former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, his former female companion V. Stiviano, and his wife Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly Sterling sued V. Stiviano, claiming that Donald had used the couple's money to buy her expensive gifts, including luxury cars and a duplex. V. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with receiving these gifts. A Los Angeles judge ruled in Shelly Sterling's favor, ordering V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million. The decision was considered a victory for the Sterling family and set a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from the recipients of such gifts. The case gained notoriety after an audio recording surfaced of Donald Sterling making racist remarks against African-Americans, which led to his ban from the NBA, a $2.5 million fine, and the termination of his ownership rights in the franchise.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's transfer window dealings and urged the club to buy four top players, including a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker, to improve their chances of winning the Premier League title. He also questioned Olivier Giroud's ability to lead the team to victory despite his 14 league goals this season, stating that Arsenal cannot win the league with him as the first-choice striker. Henry cited Chelsea's example of signing key players like Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as a model for Arsenal to follow if they wish to win the league again.

A young woman testified in court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, scared for her future relationships and struggling with depression, self-harm, and suicide attempts, broke her silence after Van Ryn was caught. She shared her experience in Sydney's District Court, highlighting her initial confusion and lack of understanding about the abuse as a child.

Arsenal teenager Serge Gnabry is set to return to the field after more than a year-long absence due to a serious knee injury. The 19-year-old midfielder, who impressed for the team last season, played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s against Reading on Monday, marking his recovery and progress towards rejoining the first team. Gnabry has not featured in a match since the Champions League last-16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March 2014. He is now feeling "better and better" and looking forward to his next game.

The passage describes the accidental death of 23-year-old accountant Jacob Phillips, who fell off a 70 ft cliff while trying to avoid paying a taxi fare. After a night out with friends in Cardiff, Phillips and his friends didn't have enough money to cover the taxi fare. They decided to run from the driver, with Phillips jumping over a fence in the dark and falling down the cliff. The driver, Dave Sidaway, had stopped chasing them when he couldn't see where he was going. Phillips was found dead at the bottom of the cliff the next day. The coroner's verdict was accidental death, as it is likely Phillips became disoriented and didn't know the danger he was in.

During last summer's passport delay fiasco, thousands of holidaymakers faced issues without receiving compensation, while passport agency managers, who made a £42 million profit, received up to £3,500 in bonuses. The government refused to provide blanket refunds to families who paid extra for rushed document processing or missed trips. The HM Passport Office struggled with 3.6 million applications, leading to over half a million passports stuck in the system by mid-June. Although the Passport Office agreed to provide urgent cases with a free fast-track service, many had already paid £30 per passport for this service and still missed trips due to late passport arrivals. Out of thousands affected, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with a total payout of £203,066. The Passport Office could not disclose the number of rejected claims due to a system failure. Ministers rejected a demand for compensation for those left out of pocket, citing it would create a precedent.

The passage describes a vintage home in Horfield, Bristol, that has remained largely unchanged since the 1930s and is now up for sale. This semi-detached property features original stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and preserved rooms, including the bathroom and kitchen, with some retro elements. The house, which has a guide price of between £200,000 and £250,000, offers a unique collection for antique lovers and could serve as a family home for those with a passion for such features. Despite some modern upgrades like double glazing, the house retains its character and charm, with original tins of food products and distinctive architectural details. Auctioneers suggest that the cost of further renovations might deter developers, making it a potentially attractive option for those who appreciate its historical integrity. The home will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith in his professional career. He became the 49ers' starter in 2012 after Smith suffered a concussion, leading the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
The passage describes "Soul Food," a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel. The movie was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage provides brief information about Anne Rice, her early life in New Orleans, Texas, and San Francisco, and details about Route 495, a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, leading to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language TV network, owned by Comcast via the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in London and Essex, met Graham Coxon at Stanway School and formed Blur, releasing their debut album 'Leisure' in 1991. Influenced by various genres, their self-titled album achieved worldwide success in 2001. Albarn's solo debut 'Everyday Robots,' co-produced by Richard Russell and released in 2014, featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, along with samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It houses many important national institutions due to its status as the country's capital.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a track by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes two related media productions: "Shooter" (2007 film) and "Shooter" (TV series). The film features Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. The TV series, starring Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, revolves around an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action upon learning of a plot to assassinate the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012, spanning eight seasons.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, which were carried out by his group members. He also received convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Despite being charged with these crimes, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He started his acting career with a TV appearance in Little House on the Prairie in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn. Penn's film debut was in Taps (1981), followed by diverse roles in the 1980s. He gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). Penn's prominence as a leading actor solidified with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), eventually winning Best Actor Oscars in 2003 for Mystic River and 2008 for Milk.

Don Bradman, born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001, was an Australian cricketer known as "The Don" and considered the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he continued to contribute to the sport as an administrator, selector, and writer for 30 years.

L.A. Reid is a prominent music executive who has held significant positions including Chairman and CEO of Epic Records, President and CEO of Arista Records, and Chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group, all under the umbrella of Sony Music Entertainment.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his involvement in rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage with members from Rage and other artists. Rage is also a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers is a multi-camera television series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015. The show spanned two seasons, totaling 34 episodes. However, it was canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, during the second season, after only four episodes had aired.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, born on September 1, 1933, was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she initially gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards, the second female governor of Texas, was known for her outspoken feminism, memorable one-liners, and was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards, who shares the same birth name, was a jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton, passing away on April 1, 1982.
Drake Bell, an independent artist, released an EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

The passage provides information about two distinct subjects. The first is "Boardwalk," a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, with Verona directing. Buffy Summers is a character played by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The passage announces that "Make It or Break It" concluded after its third season, with the series finale airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that involves computers recognizing and transcribing spoken language. It combines knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of speech recognition include voice user interfaces, domotic appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. The field has seen significant advancements through the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, which have utilized deep learning as the core technology in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, born on January 26, 1952, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, initially named the Golden State Comic Book Convention. Alf served as the chairman of the event, which eventually became known as the San Diego Comic-Con.
The passage describes "Fist of Legend" as a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," which originally starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

In a tied lead at 16 under par, France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl share the top spot, while McIlroy and Thailand's Aphibarnrat are at 15 under par. McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, overcame early setbacks to card a third consecutive 67. He is currently focusing on playing within himself and aims for a low round in the upcoming day. Despite a past ankle injury that sidelined him for several tournaments, McIlroy is targeting a third Race to Dubai title, leading Danny Willett by a significant margin with three events left after the Turkish Open.

In the passage, Sheikh Ali Salman emphasizes the importance of meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, calling for the government to provide concrete solutions and engage in dialogue with the opposition. He highlights the division within the royal family, with Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa seen as a reformist and the Prime Minister as a hardliner opposed to concessions. Sheikh Salman acknowledges the loss of faith among young protesters in the opposition parties but believes working with reformists within the royal family is the way forward. He also discusses the seven-point plan that was interrupted by the intervention of Gulf Co-operation Council troops and expresses hope for clearer US policy under Secretary of State John Kerry. Sheikh Salman urges the UK government to publicly address the issue of human rights abuses in Bahrain and calls for the release of opposition leaders and activists sentenced on torture-derived evidence.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. He worked with leading orchestras globally and was a significant figure in the early-music movement. Hogwood established the AAM in 1973 and directed it across six continents for 30 years, during which the academy produced over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, which was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. He studied at Cambridge University and later worked as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. His contributions to historically informed music were widely acknowledged, and his legacy continues to influence the music world.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide cases, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. This represents half the figure from nine years ago, with only one case from 2015-16 remaining unresolved. The most common method of killing was with a sharp instrument, particularly a knife, involved in 26 of the 29 cases. 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. While the overall homicide rate has decreased, violent crime and sexual crime rates have increased, with a 27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasizes the need for continued efforts in education, enforcement, and supporting communities at risk of violent crime.

In a Premier League match, Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first win of the season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but the team failed to capitalize on numerous chances, conceding goals from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe. Despite being down a man, Bournemouth could not find an equalizer. Coach Howe acknowledged the team's struggle to score despite creating many chances and emphasized the importance of moving forward from such setbacks.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's stance on preventing migrant deaths at sea. He argues that the only way to stop these deaths is to "stop the boats," a policy that involves detaining migrants and taking them to offshore processing camps for resettlement. The New York Times has criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality." The paper also warned European leaders against adopting similar policies. While Australia has not responded to the editorial, Mr. Abbott maintains his position, citing the tragic image of Syrian child Alan Kurdi as a reason to stop the boats. Additionally, Mr. Abbott sparked controversy by comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis, a comparison criticized by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry as an unfortunate and unjust comparison to the systematic genocide committed by the Nazis. Mr. Abbott later clarified that he was not in the business of ranking evil but stood by his comments.

The passage describes the escalating conflict between the US and Russia over the situation in Aleppo, Syria. The US accuses Russia and the Syrian government of intensifying attacks against civilians, particularly in the city of Aleppo. In response, the US warned it would halt talks with Russia unless Moscow ceased bombing Aleppo. Russia regrets the US move and accuses the US of shifting blame for the collapse of a recent truce. The main trauma hospital in eastern Aleppo was hit in an air strike, and hundreds, including children, have died since the government forces aimed to take full control of the city after the truce lapsed.
