FGW claims the change is to align the route with its other services. Train companies can increase 'unregulated' fares, which make up around half of their total revenue, in three windows every year. Notable fare increases include an 87% increase for passengers traveling from Charlbury and a 24.5% increase for an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after thugs threw a brick at him through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester. He and his new wife Elaine, 54, were sitting in their front room when the thugs began pelting their window with stones. When one brick broke the glass, Mr. Young opened the door to confront the attackers, only to be hit in the left eye by another brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The couple, who got married just three weeks prior, now feels unsafe in their home and plans to move to Southport. Police have launched an investigation but have found no clear motive for the attack, suspecting it could be a case of "yobs messing around."

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, who missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident, has signed a new one-year contract extension after a successful return from injury. The 25-year-old former England under-19 international had an ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Tom will be available for the start of the season, committing himself to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Tom's exceptional character and hard work, hoping the new contract will boost his confidence and continue his good form.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. He underwent treatment, including chemotherapy, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, while wearing a Ninja Turtle superhero mask to help him feel stronger and braver. Harley's story gained widespread attention, leading to support from Nickelodeon and cancer research charities. After a year of battling the disease, Harley was declared cancer-free and will continue to have regular check-ups. His bravery earned him Cancer Research UK's Little Star Award, and he became the face of their Kids and Teens campaign. Neuroblastoma is a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, making it the second most common solid tumor in childhood.

Tim Sherwood advises 19-year-old Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career before deciding on his international future, as Grealish is sought after by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood is impressed with Grealish's performance in Aston Villa's FA Cup semi-final win against Liverpool and believes Grealish should continue to establish himself in the Villa first team before making a decision on his international allegiance. Grealish's father, Kevin, also supports the notion of concentrating on club football first before addressing international choices.

The passage discusses the high landing fees at certain airports for private jets, which can reach thousands of dollars. It highlights some of the most expensive airports for landing fees, such as Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, and Salzburg Airport in Austria. The private jet industry is a growing trend, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe. The busiest weekends for private jet companies occur during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. The market for private jets is worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, making it a significant industry for the rich and famous.

In the passage, Katie Gallegos takes her dog Cooper and his friend Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat. While Daisy eats her ice cream slowly, Cooper quickly eats his in one bite. The video of this event has been watched over seven million times. Some people criticize Gallegos for giving her dogs ice cream, but she insists it's fine as Cooper is healthy and she controls how much Daisy eats. The dogs also enjoy a "pup-uccino" from Starbucks, which is a cup of whipped cream without coffee.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year deal. He initially joined as assistant to Allan Johnston and took over when Johnston resigned in February. Locke has only lost one of his seven games since taking charge at Rugby Park, and the appointment was finalized after a successful interim period, with a press conference scheduled for Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims that her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, was threatened with suspension by Seminole County Elementary school due to the use of essential oils manufactured by Doterra. These oils, applied to Logan's head and neck, are said to help him stay calm and focused. Jessica Kemp asserts that Logan has been using the oils throughout the year, but a teacher's aide recently complained about the smell being a distraction. The local school board sent a letter stating that the oils have caused a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat of suspension, Kemp plans to fight the decision, arguing that the oils have a positive impact on her son. The school district later clarified that Logan would not be suspended, calling it a health issue. The family uses Doterra oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, which the company describes as being both beautifully and powerfully fragrant.

A fire at a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, the Sandpiper complex, destroyed 90 condos on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze was intense, causing damage to nearby buildings, and smoke could be seen from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but were unable to enter the summer homes. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with some reports suggesting it started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

The passage describes the Queen's passion for horses and her enjoyment of riding, particularly her fondness for her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma. At 88 years old, the Queen was seen riding through Windsor Great Park with a groom accompanying her on another of her ponies. She prefers not to wear a helmet, opting for a silk scarf instead, due to her hair. The Queen has been an avid horse lover since receiving her first Shetland pony, Peggy, at the age of four. She has ridden throughout her life but has reduced her time in the saddle due to a knee injury. The Queen also breeds Fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud and takes a keen interest in all her horses and ponies. Fell ponies are a hardy, ancient breed that have been roaming the moors of Cumbria since the Neolithic period and have a rich history with various invaders, such as the Romans and Vikings. Today, they remain popular riding horses for people of all ages, including the Queen.

In a Brisbane neighborhood, a noise-related argument between 55-year-old Leon Yeaman and 28-year-old Phillip Pama escalated, resulting in Yeaman's death and Pama being charged with manslaughter. Pama, a father of three and shift worker, allegedly killed Yeaman with a single punch after Yeaman continued making noise despite Pama's request to lower the volume. Yeaman, described as kind and generous, was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed playing loud music. Pama, who has no history of violence, was granted conditional bail, and the case is set to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, who was jilted by 15-year-old Damian Vanya after a year-long relationship, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder him. She offered 100,000 Rubles (£1,400) for the hit. However, the police set up a sting operation with an undercover officer posing as a hitman. Simonova was recorded asking for the teenager to be beaten, have his arms and legs broken, and to slowly bleed to death. After handing over the money, she was arrested and now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Damian Vanya expressed relief at the outcome and hoped that Simonova would be imprisoned for a long time.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, has shared that he speaks to God daily but never discusses football, even with his wife Matilde Faria. He and his family are aware of poverty and have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. Mourinho tries to separate his professional and family life, admitting to having a strong faith but not attending church regularly. He only prays for personal matters and not for his team, Chelsea. Despite his competitive and sometimes arrogant persona, Mourinho considers himself a good person, family man, and friend. Chelsea is currently at the top of the league and is set to play against struggling QPR.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before retiring in 2007, made a special appearance on the April 1st edition of the show, taking over hosting duties from Drew Carey. At 91 years old, Barker appeared energetic as he led the first game, "Lucky Seven," before passing the hosting back to Carey. This marked the first time in eight years that Barker participated in the show, and he demonstrated seamless chemistry with the contestants.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested for attempted burglary and destruction of property in Washington D.C. He was a part of the foreign missions branch, which deals with U.S. diplomatic activities. Following the arrest, the agency revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. This incident occurred two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave for alleged misconduct. The Homeland Security Department's inspector general is investigating both cases, along with other incidents involving the agency, which is responsible for protecting the president and his family.

A photographer named Atif Saeed got very close to a lion at a safari park in Lahore, Pakistan. He wanted to take a picture to show the lion's character and status. He went near the lion with just a camera, and managed to take a few photos from only 10 feet away. But the camera's clicking sound alerted the lion, and Atif had to quickly run back to his car. He was brave, but admits he might not be able to do it again.

The New York City police have released an image of a heart tattoo with the name "Monique" on it, found on an unidentified woman who died last month in Brooklyn. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Despite efforts by paramedics, she was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had no identification on her, and the cause of her death is still pending a medical examiner's report. The police are asking anyone with information about the woman to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck due to their inability to afford a traditional property. The project took a year and a half and cost around $25,000. The home is located in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by nature. The couple is now nearly self-sufficient, with solar panels providing most of their power, a wood-fired stove for warmth, and water from a nearby spring.

In the given passage, researchers claim that children who share iPads in class show significantly better performance in early literacy tests compared to those who don't. The passage mentions that Courtney Blackwell, from Northwestern University, found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classes over an academic year outscored their peers who were in classes with no iPads or where each student had their own device. The shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher than students who used the device individually and non-iPad users. Blackwell's findings suggest that it is the collaborative learning around the technology, not just the collaboration itself, that makes the difference. The passage implies that schools should reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

The passage describes a two-legged piglet that has become an internet sensation due to its ability to walk on its front trotters. Born without back legs, the piglet has mastered balancing on its front legs and can be seen in a video taking unsteady steps and foraging for food. Despite several close calls, the piglet maintains its balance and happily interacts with its littermates, who all have full legs. The piglet belongs to a farmer in Sichuan Province, China, and has attracted many villagers to come and see it. This piglet is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China, as a rabbit at a zoo also became a star by walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone had come in on lap 25 for tires and fuel but spun while exiting the pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated with stitches for a leg cut and released. The race, which took place after hours of rain, saw many cars struggle with traction. Dracone did not finish the race, ending up in 23rd place.

In the provided passage, a man named Milton Vieira Severiano brutally attacked and killed his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, due to jealousy. The incident occurred in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano first smashed her head into concrete paving 11 times and then shot her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime, stating his jealousy over men looking at his wife. Cicera was a member of the dance troupe "Jaula das Gostozuedas." After the attack, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police after crashing it. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his possession. He now faces a potential life sentence in jail.

In a candid interview with Women's Weekly Australia, Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, which nearly led her to take her own life. Wilson, 41, explained how anxiety made her feel isolated and unable to see the point in continuing her life. A combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family contributed to her feeling that her life was no longer worth living. Although she struggled with these issues in her younger years, Wilson has recently found some peace with her anxiety, acknowledging it as a part of who she is. She believes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that recognizing this connection is essential for addressing the growing number of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. Wilson also noted that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," with Beyond Blue reporting that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, often leading to depression.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, faced second-degree assault charges after hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The ex-girlfriend was found using heroin in Curtin's bathroom and refused to leave. Prosecutors later dropped the charge, stating Curtin's actions were "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law allows the use of physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassment and threats towards Curtin. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a six-year prison sentence.

In the passage, Gemma, a pit bull in California, is caught on film being fed treats. Her owner tricks her by including a broccoli spear among the treats. Gemma reacts with disgust, chomping on the vegetable before spitting it out on the floor. The passage hopes that the two children she lives with will not follow her example and learn to enjoy vegetables. Gemma's other activities include sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized for a mistake that occurred when a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue arose after the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was shut down in 2011, had its URL address taken over by the porn site. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website and clarified that it is not associated with the external site, offering apologies for any inconvenience caused. The bank assured that its website remained secure, and its internet banking service continued to function normally.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after a fire broke out on the first floor of their Clinton home on Sunday morning. Marcus called 911, stayed calm during the 11-minute call, and provided firefighters with instructions to rescue them. He also comforted his sister during the call. Prince George's County firefighters entered the room, breaking a window to reach the siblings. Marcus was handed out the window to a rescuer, and the firefighter later gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both children were taken to a hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while three other family members escaped on their own and were also hospitalized.

The passage describes the phenomenon of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, located on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the stunning images of the neon glow, which illuminated one of Australia's popular beaches. He described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display was observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers, from the University of New South Wales, identified the algae as Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn, with 90% of occurrences being due to natural causes. The glow is a result of the carnivorous cell's defense mechanism, as it preys on another type of algae called diatoms. Suthers reassures that there is no need to be concerned about the algae, as it is a natural occurrence.

New tests can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors, determining their aggressiveness and helping patients avoid chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened in a lab, and women receive information on their risk of the disease returning within days. For some, the test can accurately predict a low risk, similar to or better than those who undergo chemotherapy. Currently, most women with breast cancer are given chemotherapy after tumor removal to prevent recurrence, despite its severe side effects. The newest test, Endopredict, costs around £2,500 and is mostly available privately, but experts hope it will soon be accessible on the NHS. These tests allow patients to make informed decisions about undergoing chemotherapy, potentially saving costs and reducing the need for the treatment.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medevacs in the last nine years. HMS Illustrious also had at least one woman airlifted before its decommissioning. A strict "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding or during leave. This data comes after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member, leading to a military investigation. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. In 2013, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering their pregnancies, due to strict military rules banning pregnant individuals from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying radioactive material was discovered on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential drone-based terrorism. This incident occurred on the same day a court approved the restart of two reactors at a nuclear power plant, a decision unpopular among many Japanese citizens. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle with radioactive traces, has prompted discussions on regulating drone operations and addressing terrorism threats. Currently, Japanese law only restricts drone flights around airports, leaving most of Tokyo, including government buildings, unrestricted.

A security guard from Zhejiang province in China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother to work with him on the back of his motorbike every day. He is concerned that she might get lost if left alone at home, as she used to wander off and get lost in the mountains. After his father's passing, Lu had no one else to care for her, and his wife and son are away in a different city. To ensure her safety, he ties a sash around both their waists during the 4-kilometer ride to work, which takes an hour. His employers, a bank, have provided his mother with a room to stay in during work hours, and Lu checks on her frequently. He feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to raising her children.

The passage discusses a major study on alcohol use in the United States, which found that heavy drinking increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, primarily due to rising rates among women. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, defines heavy drinking as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men during the past month. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The increase in women's drinking habits is attributed to changing social norms. The study also highlights that 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers in 2012. Approximately 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, with the cost of excessive drinking estimated at more than $220 billion per year. Public health experts offer various explanations for the increase in excessive drinking, including the normalization of women drinking like men, the influx of wealthy professionals in tech jobs, and the decrease in alcohol taxes in real dollars.

The passage discusses concerns raised by UN officials regarding the overuse of caesarean sections by doctors, which they claim puts the health of women and their babies at risk. The procedure should only be performed when medically necessary due to potential infections and fatalities. Currently, over a quarter of women giving birth in England have a caesarean, a significant increase since the early 1990s. The World Health Organisation recommends an ideal rate of 10-15% due to dangers and costs involved. Caesarean sections can lead to complications, diverting funds from other patients. The WHO contradicts NHS guidelines, which allow the procedure for anxious women or those with certain conditions. The overuse of caesareans is criticized, with previous research indicating that one in ten can cause infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for a week, and sold the owners' items in a yard sale. She was caught and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner found her in the house and she claimed to own it before fleeing. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the police department.

A lost iPhone was returned to its owner, Bella Crooke, after police officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and humorous messages on her Facebook page to track her down. The phone was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party and dialed her number upon realizing it was missing. A security guard informed her that it had been left at the police station. When Bella finally arrived to claim her phone, she did not have to provide her name as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police's unique method of communication garnered a positive response from Bella's friends, who called the officers "legends." Bella has since set a password for her phone.

In the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa, a baby hippo was tragically caught in a fight between two adult hippos. The five-day-old calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface, eventually dying from its injuries hours after the altercation. The calf's mother and other members of the herd watched helplessly as the incident unfolded. Stacey Farrell, a 30-year-old tour operator, witnessed the event and reported that the mother tried to rescue her baby but was unable to do so effectively. The two adult males had been fighting for some time, and the mother had attempted to keep her calf safe by staying with her herd.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is listed for £575,000, significantly cheaper than surrounding properties. However, it has only three years left on the lease, with costs amounting to £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, similar to local rental rates. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth over £6 million. The apartment, requiring modernization, features three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, lift access, parking, and a communal garden. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and lease extension negotiations may cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing registers to be non-functional. As a result, baristas gave away free drinks. The issue was resolved, and stores were expected to open as usual the next day. The outage began on the east coast in the early evening and on the west coast in the late afternoon. Starbucks did not explain the cause of the outage. The company offered free drinks and baked goods to customers during the outage. Some locations closed early due to the system failure. The outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, and it also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Many customers took advantage of the free drinks and shared their experiences on social media.

Terrorists are being trained in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, for the purpose of radicalizing Muslims, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These individuals participate in ordinary community activities with an ulterior motive. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998 when Abu Hamza allegedly sent a group of 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons in Powys. The rugged terrain of the area is also used by the British military for training soldiers, including elite forces like the SAS. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in North Wales, and in 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for plotting a series of terror attacks on Britain. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is believed to have studied Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, near Llanybydder, which was set up by Iraqi clerics. Detective Constable Gareth Jones emphasized the importance

The passage describes the discovery of a rare Omura's whale on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia, which is the first sighting of the species in the region and only the second in the country. The whale was found after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn hit the area. Initially, it was challenging for Department of Parks and Wildlife staff to identify the 5.68-meter juvenile female, but DNA profiling confirmed it as an Omura's whale. This find is highly significant for whale scientists as very little is known about the species, which was only described in scientific journals for the first time in 2003. Omura's whales are typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. They have a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, such as 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses the debate over whether a woman's hormones should be considered a factor in presidential candidacy. Texas businesswoman Cheryl Rios argues against women being president, stating that hormones make them irrational and more likely to start unnecessary wars. However, studies show that women leaders tend to take fewer unnecessary risks than men. The passage highlights the gender bias that women face in the workplace and how this bias affects their opportunities and leadership potential. It emphasizes the importance of overcoming gender stereotypes and biases for the betterment of society, economy, and families.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and portraying Winston Churchill, is selling his collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction to downsize his home. The auction includes over 200 items, such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, Victorian furniture, a portrait of Hardy holding a longbow, and various other paintings, swords, and crystal chandeliers. Hardy, a military history expert and a close friend of Richard Burton, has built up the collection through his interest in classic literature and military history. The auction will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and has been on the run from police since failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was found. The well-being check was called in by an out-of-state family member, and an initial investigation determined that foul play was involved. Shemansky, who is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness, was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for attempted suicide. His estranged wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors believe the stress of divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. The murder weapon has been recovered, but authorities have not yet confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication, and anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The passage states that the city of Eugene, United States, has been granted the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council. This decision was made to take advantage of a unique strategic opportunity to hold the championships in the USA for the first time, bypassing the usual bidding process. Eugene had previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack expressed his delight at the decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the National Olympic Committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process. The passage also mentions Mo Farah's gold medal win in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, set a honey trap to lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in an attempt to steal his winnings. Granger befriended Hassan after spotting him at a London casino and used her good looks to receive gifts, cash, and trips from him. She then convinced Hassan to invite her to his flat, where her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home for the hidden winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years in prison, while Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and received life sentences with a minimum of 36 years.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling during the second half of the season, which is a continuing trend. Initially, he was on track to break the Premier League record for assists, but his form has significantly declined. Despite his success with Chelsea, questions remain about his durability. Fabregas' former club, Barcelona, released a statement highlighting his post-Christmas slump, where his contributions to the team gradually decreased as each season drew to a close. His assist record has dropped off since mid-January, and he is now on track to fall short of Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists in a Premier League season. However, Chelsea still has nine games left, and if Fabregas can regain his form, the Premier League title could be secured within weeks. Manager Jose Mourinho hopes that Fabregas' recent assist for Diego Costa in the game against Hull City signals a late-season resurgence.

West Ham is in talks to sign Jamaican teenager Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial at the club's academy. Beckford, 17, from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered a top prospect from the Caribbean. West Ham is close to finalizing the deal for Beckford while also announcing affordable season ticket prices at the Olympic Stadium, starting at £289, to attract a full 54,000-capacity crowd in the 2016-17 Premier League season.

The police have halted their investigation into a brutal assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, by masked protesters wielding iron bars three months ago, despite substantial evidence. Lane, who was left with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss, criticized the police's "pathetic" efforts. Wiltshire police have suspended the inquiry due to insufficient evidence, despite being provided with a video of the incident, a dossier containing names and car registration numbers of suspected attackers, and an identification photo of the main suspect. The assault occurred during a hunt using an artificial scent, with protesters spraying hounds with citronella to disrupt the chase. The decision to drop the investigation has angered hunt supporters and the countryside alliance, which is advocating for a ban on face coverings by saboteurs to facilitate criminal prosecution.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece of Al Qaeda, was killed in a US counterterrorism operation in January. A US citizen, Gadahn spoke against the US on behalf of the terrorist organization. His death, along with that of another US citizen and Al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq, was announced by the White House in March. Both Gadahn and Farouq were not specifically targeted in the operations during which they died. Al Qaeda's most prominent English-language propagandist, Gadahn rose through the ranks in Pakistan following 9/11, appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks on various Western targets. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda and was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists."

The passage describes the rise of a young basketball prodigy, five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, in China. Mai has gained fame through a viral video showcasing his impressive basketball skills, which have won him fans across the basketball-crazed country. The video features him scoring multiple hoops and dexterously dribbling two basketballs at once. His talent has drawn comparisons to China's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming, and has stunned online commentators, many of whom question the authenticity of his abilities. Some viewers express a desire to start their lives over, feeling ashamed of their own basketball skills in comparison to the young phenom.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, is now backing Hacked Off in their campaign against the "biased and unfair" Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO). Hacked Off seeks the establishment of a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The news of O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off may be embarrassing for the group, given PIE's history and objectives.

On Thursday, the iconic Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, allowing models to walk through the empty pool and along the break wall. The event featured a monochrome capsule collection by Ten Pieces, a lifestyle brand that produces unisex clothing designed to be worn in 20 different ways and suitable for day to night wear. The show took place under clear skies on an unusually warm 28 degrees Celcius day, with beachgoers and passers-by stopping to watch the unconventional runway presentation.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a day with his family at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, posing with and feeding a rare white tiger, as well as enjoying time with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. The family enjoyed a safari park experience and adventure park activities. Recently, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, amidst speculation about potential fights with British rival Kell Brook and others like Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the inclusion of Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name on an Israeli memorial at Mount Herzl, which commemorates fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His name appeared on the memorial wall ahead of Israel's Memorial Day, with an image of an Israeli flag and "Blood of the Maccabees" flowers, a common symbol for the day. However, his family and Almagor, an organization representing victims of terror, objected to his inclusion, stating that his death was a rogue attack and not a terror-related incident. Almagor demanded that his name be removed from the memorial, and following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel decided to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial, as well as from their website. A panel of judges is currently hearing evidence against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing.

In the passage, a California-based YouTube user named Lionel Hutz captures a humorous scenario where his young son repeatedly attempts to use the family cat as a makeshift pillow in the garden. The son chases the cat, lies down on it, and the cat responds by moving to a different spot. This cycle repeats several times until the cat retreats indoors. A subsequent video shows the son and cat reconciled, with the son feeding the cat treats.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about selling marijuana and officers stealing money and drugs from him in 2007. Kushner's criminal history was not known to the academy when he was hired in 2010. He had passed a background check and the 2007 charges were expunged. Kushner was arrested again in 2011 but maintains his innocence. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, based on testimonies from 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) producing chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire. The incident occurred after an oil leak at an oil storage facility. Five of the injured were treated for cuts from broken glass. Over 600 firefighters were dispatched, and the fire is now under control. The plant had previously been the site of protests due to its potential environmental impact, leading to its relocation from a more populated area to its current location.

Aston Villa player Jack Grealish insists on keeping his socks low and using children's size shinpads due to superstition, despite referees' requests to pull them up. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR and expressed his appreciation for the manager's faith in him, hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite being taken out of a medically induced coma. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed her sadness and hope for a miracle. Bobbi Kristina does not respond to visitors or familiar voices and has a tracheostomy in her throat. While her condition has improved, her future quality of life remains uncertain as she begins a long rehabilitation process. Bobby Brown announced that she is awake and watching him, but the extent of her improvement is still unclear.

Russia is on the verge of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead against Germany, as Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova's victory came after Svetlana Kuznetsova won against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players faced issues with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki having 63 unforced errors. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

The passage discusses the ongoing impact of severe weather events in New South Wales, Australia. Last week, the region experienced wild weather, including heavy rain, strong winds, and flooding, which caused significant damage and required assistance from the State Emergency Service (SES). Despite the recent calamity, meteorologists warn that another storm is predicted to hit the area later this week, potentially bringing more heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The SES is concerned that additional storms will hinder clean-up efforts, with thousands of jobs still to be completed. The passage highlights the particular vulnerability of the Hunter region, which was severely affected by the previous storm. Weather predictions indicate a trough of low pressure forming along the coast, with the heaviest impact expected in the far northern parts of the state. The SES is preparing for the possibility of more severe weather and urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further devastation.

The passage discusses model Nina Moric's response to claims in the Italian media that she attempted suicide. Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied the claims on Instagram, stating that she did not try to take her own life. Instead, she explained that she was treated in the hospital after collapsing due to low blood pressure from a domestic accident. Moric posted photographs of her injuries on Instagram and clarified that her boyfriend was not present during the incident, contrary to some reports. She expressed her shock at the suicide claims and assured her fans that she was recovering well and only needed rest. The passage also briefly mentions Moric's past marriage to famous paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

The passage discusses the anticipation surrounding the arrival of Kate and William's second child, with the British public hoping for a baby girl and favoring the name Diana, after William's mother, Princess Diana. Other popular names mentioned are Alice and Charlotte. If the baby is a boy, 13% of people would like the name James. A quarter of the 2,200 people polled hope for a female baby, while only 3% wish for a younger brother for Prince George. The majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, Afghanistan, killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were heading to a rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group claimed it. The attack occurred at 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer, as confirmed by his representative. Despite having a successful seven-year tenure at the club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back could not reach an agreement for a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, announced that Alves had turned down a three-year contract extension dependent on his participation in 60% of matches, and the negotiations have concluded. Consequently, Alves will depart from the Nou Camp this summer.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently playing for Argentinian giants Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca. Osvaldo believes that the duo would fit well at Boca and that their South-American style of play and abilities would make them perfect for the team. He also thinks that the fans at La Bombonera would love to have Pirlo and Totti, who are well-established and highly regarded in world football. Pirlo is known as one of the best midfielders, while Totti is a Roma legend who Osvaldo feels would be just as loved in Argentina.

Amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton, an event that garnered hundreds of thousands of views online. Despite the fall, Ferguson was back to work the next day with only a cut on his nose. He described the incident as a blur and was grateful for the support from fellow jockeys. Ferguson humorously considered a gymnastics career following the incident, but remains undeterred from continuing his racing career.

The passage discusses the release of the movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron" and how James Haskell, a London Wasps captain and England flanker, celebrated the event by posting a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram. Haskell has a rugby career that spans various teams and countries, starting with the Wasps in 2002, then moving to Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders in New Zealand. After his stint abroad, he returned to the Wasps in 2012 and has since made over 100 appearances for the club, becoming an integral part of both the team and the England squad with 57 caps to date.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide leg trousers as a fashion trend, particularly for the spring/summer 2015 season. This style is seen as an alternative to the popular skinny jean and is favored by celebrities like Louise Redknapp. The key to styling wide leg trousers is proportion, pairing them with high heels and simple tops to maintain a modern and chic look. Denim is the easiest material to try this trend, with brands like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney showcasing wide leg styles on the runway. The trend is versatile and does not require ideal weather to be flattering, with tips provided on how to shop and find inspiration.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with screening the film "American Sniper" as part of Umix, a series of social events for students, despite objections from some students who signed a petition against it. The movie, starring Bradley Cooper, depicts Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history. Some students believed the film's portrayal of the Iraq war negatively represented the Middle East and its people. However, a counter-petition urged the school to reconsider the cancellation. University officials acknowledged the mistake in canceling the film, emphasizing the importance of freedom of expression and offering an alternative family-friendly movie, "Paddington," for those who preferred not to attend "American Sniper."

Two French male tourists attempted to set a quokka alight with an aerosol spray on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. The tourists, aged 18 and 24, were questioned, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas, similar in size to domestic cats, are native to small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island.

The passage narrates the story of 102-year-old Alice Barker, a dancer from the 1930s and 1940s who performed in famous New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar, alongside notable figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Despite being captured in motion pictures, Barker had never seen herself dance as her photographs, memorabilia, and videos were lost over the years. Recently, Mark Cantor from Jazz-on-Film.com and some volunteers compiled a video of "Soundies" – early music videos – and presented it to Barker at her nursing home. Witnessing herself dance for the first time, the timeless performer expressed her delight, calling the experience "fabulous."

The passage discusses the decline of car washing as a Sunday routine in Britain, with a third of men admitting to never washing their own car. The study shows that three-quarters of women also do not wash their own car, preferring to take it to a car wash instead. Factors contributing to this decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicle sizes, and more time-consuming activities such as shopping and watching football on Sundays. However, cars are more likely to be washed by their owners during holidays. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners do it least often. Cities with the highest likelihood of people washing their own cars are Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, while Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh have the lowest rates.

The passage discusses Martin Skrtel's praise for Steven Gerrard's impact on him since joining Liverpool in 2008. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and an iconic figure for the team. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool into the final against Arsenal before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements for Gerrard and will try to help them integrate into the team. Both players could return to the lineup after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, marking his first ace on the course and contributing to a record-equaling five hole-in-ones for the day. Playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus's feat was later matched by Camilo Villegas, who also scored two aces. However, Villegas lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, who holds the record for the youngest person to wear a green jacket (achieved in 1963) and has won the Masters six times (last in 1986), is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

The passage describes a series of storms that hit Kansas and Missouri, causing tornado warnings and damage. Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas, with one tornado reported 6 miles northwest of Goddard and another in Potosi, Missouri. The storms moved northeast, posing risks to communities, and were considered particularly dangerous due to occurring at night. Tornado sightings were also reported in southwestern Kansas. The storms caused wind damage, flooding, and hail in affected areas. The National Weather Service warned of more storms expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

The passage discusses the case of an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, who has pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting a man, Eric Harris, whom he claimed he intended to subdue with a Taser. Bates was granted permission to go to the Bahamas for a family vacation, which upset Harris's family, who criticized Bates for showing apathy towards the shooting and Eric's life. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The incident occurred during a weapons sting operation on April 2, and Bates has claimed the shooting was accidental. Bates has apologized to the Harris family, and Sheriff Stanley Glanz has also apologized. The lawyer for Harris's family claims that Bates was not qualified to be on the force but received preferential treatment due to his friendship with the sheriff and donations to the agency. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has denied allegations that Bates' records were forged. Recently, one of Bates' lawyers released his training documents, stating they prove his proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish featherweight fighter, is set to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11. Prior to the fight, McGregor unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, symbolizing his ferocity in the ring. The fight will be Aldo's eighth defense of his belt in Las Vegas, but McGregor believes he has more motivation to win than Aldo does to defend his title. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor even grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 home supporters, highlighting their tense relationship.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after skolling a beer at an Australian rules football function. While some cheered his actions, cultural studies professor Julie Robert argued that the Prime Minister should be advocating against binge drinking and not promoting a culture where drinking is about how quickly and how much one can drink. She warned that such behavior can encourage people to forget their limits while demonstrating how much or quickly they can drink. Critics stated that Mr. Abbott should set an example that one doesn't have to drink heavily to be considered a "true blue aussie bloke." Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Mr. Abbott, saying there was "nothing wrong" with his actions and that he promotes a healthy lifestyle through exercise.

The passage discusses a significant increase in HIV cases in Indiana, particularly in Scott County, which is linked to intravenous drug users and the use of the painkiller Opana. The number of confirmed HIV cases is 120, with 10 preliminary positive cases. This outbreak has prompted a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. Since its approval, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants, and 1,400 used syringes have been returned. The future of the needle exchange program and related legislation is uncertain, as Governor Pence and others have concerns about promoting drug use. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that between 50% and 90% of people with Hepatitis C are also infected with HIV, indicating a potential for further outbreaks. The passage also mentions the challenges of funding needle exchange programs due to a federal ban on public funding since 1989.

In the passage, a dedicated Arsenal fan creates a test for his girlfriend, Saskia, to quiz her on his favorite football club. She scores an impressive 43.5 out of 50, earning an 'A' grade and securing her relationship. The test includes multiple-choice questions, tables, and an 'in your own words' section, resembling a school exam. Saskia's creative answers and knowledge of Arsenal impressed many, with some calling her 'proper gf material.' The boyfriend's approach to testing Saskia's knowledge sparked mixed reactions, with some finding it excessive and others seeing it as a fun challenge.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. He helped carry out undercover stings around the world and played a significant role in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro is now facing deportation as he was not rewarded with US citizenship as promised and now lives in the US illegally. The DEA refused to help Toro with his citizenship after he went public with his plight, and he is scared to return to Colombia due to threats against his life.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after being allegedly raped by five men from her village. She is currently in a critical condition with 70% burns at Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi. The incident occurred in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district when the girl went outside her house to relieve herself. The accused men have been arrested. This case highlights the heightened sensitivity towards sexual assault in India, following the ban of a documentary called "India's Daughter," which discussed the gang rape and murder of a student in Delhi. The documentary's ban was due to fears that it would cause further disorder, as recent attacks in India have led to street protests demanding better protection for women.

In the upcoming Manchester derby at Old Trafford, Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has announced that Robin van Persie will not be playing due to lack of fitness, despite the player claiming he was fit to feature in the game. Van Gaal is looking forward to the match and hopes to gain a victory, which could potentially place United as high as third in the table and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture later in the summer. Van Gaal also mentioned that Manchester City will be a tough challenge and that he does not view the game as one of revenge for the previous loss. Additionally, Van Gaal ruled out a potential return for Luke Shaw, deeming him not fit enough to play. United's players have been training ahead of the crucial match, with Wayne Rooney, Angel di Maria, Juan Mata, Radamel Falcao, Marcos Rojo, and Ander Herrera preparing to take on City.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was in response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal and aimed to raise awareness of the financial struggles fans face to attend matches. Banners were displayed inside and outside the stadium, criticizing the high ticket prices. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. Supporters called for tangible reductions in ticket prices to make football more accessible for working-class fans.

A newborn baby, Star Reader, diagnosed with life-threatening liver condition biliary atresia, was saved by a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader. Neither parent was a suitable match, and after unsuccessful attempts to unblock Star's bile ducts, a liver transplant became the only option. Shanell, tested as an ideal candidate, donated part of her liver without hesitation, saving Star's life. Star underwent the operation in November, spent six weeks in the hospital, and has since made a good recovery, now on blood tests, liver function tests, and anti-rejection medication for life.

In the Audi Football Challenge, Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian competed in a series of head-to-head contests. Hazard and Ake won the first round by scoring more goals into the boot of a car from close range, with a 5-3 victory. The second round involved shooting balls into a convertible Audi from long range, where Hazard and Ake again emerged victorious, leading 6-0. The final game saw Remy and Willian winning by scoring from long range into the top of a convertible Audi. However, during the challenge, Willian accidentally broke the wing mirror of one of the Audis with a shot, but it was not required for them to pay for the damage.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash in 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. He initially claimed to be trying to commit suicide by driving at high speed into an oncoming SUV. The crash resulted in the death of 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé, 29-year-old Jason Timmons. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated that he was not suicidal. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His attorneys argued that he was suffering from multiple health issues, including ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, and the advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

Lacey Spears, convicted of killing her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul by poisoning him with salt, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his desire for her to die in prison on Facebook. The judge mentioned that Spears suffers from a mental illness, and the crime was 'unfathomable in its cruelty.' Prosecutors claimed she made her son ill for attention, while her lawyer argued she was a hardworking single mother who loved her son unconditionally. Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict.

The passage discusses concerns over two new strains of influenza, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which led to a significant number of deaths in Europe and the United States. In response, scientists have developed an improved vaccine that includes protection against these strains, although its arrival in Australia is a month later than anticipated. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians, will have access to free government-funded flu shots from April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasizes the importance of getting the vaccine, which also protects against the H1N1 strain. He hopes the modified vaccine will prevent more deaths per capita than experienced in the northern hemisphere. The vaccine to be used in the next northern winter will be the same as the one being introduced in Australia. Dr. Hampson encourages people to book their flu shots now, especially those not in high-risk groups but potentially interacting with high-risk individuals, to help protect vulnerable populations.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism over the tomb's condition, as described in a National Geographic magazine article, and potential budget cuts that could threaten the management of the historic site. The tomb, located in Springfield, Illinois, has undergone significant repairs and renovations, costing over $2.5 million. However, the article criticized the tomb for having "all the historical character of an office lobby." Additionally, Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, which would result in its integration into another department. The tomb's hours of operation and staff have already been reduced due to previous budget cuts, raising concerns about the site's future. Despite the criticism, supporters of the tomb argue that the National Geographic portrayal was unfair, and the tomb is in excellent physical condition after recent renovations.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 90s and early 2000s fashion trends that are making a comeback, such as JNCO jeans, chokers, berry-colored lips, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts. It highlights several specific trends from that era that were popularized by celebrities and then abandoned, only to be revived recently. These trends include the bucket hat, camouflage print, wearing multiple designer prints or denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The passage provides examples of celebrities who wore these items in the past and those who are currently sporting them.

In the given passage, various trending stories are summarized. Four rainbows were captured in the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by a fashion CEO. China is cracking down on hiring exotic dancers for wakes, forcing families to find alternative ways to cheer mourners. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a UK interview when asked about his private life. The Kardashians have started a new trend with the #KylieJennerChallenge for lip plumping. A 102-year-old Alice Barker went back in time with the help of filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs was rejected, with accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," and Johnny Depp is unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer. A pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombed his son's special moment.

At the Miami Open, Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory with a giant cake after defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki to progress to the semi-finals. Williams's hopes of meeting her sister Venus were dashed as Venus lost to Spain's Carla Suarez Navarro. As the world no 1, Williams aimed to stay alive in the tournament, which is considered her hometown event. She secured a match against Romania's Simona Halep after Halep beat Sloane Stephens. Williams seeks revenge against Lisicki, who defeated her at Wimbledon 2013.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani activist, was tragically shot dead at her second-floor cafe, T2F, in Karachi, after hosting a discussion on a controversial topic. Known for her advocacy of free speech, human rights, and progressive values, Mahmud had become a symbol of humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan. Despite receiving death threats in the past, she continued to champion secular wisdom and provide a space for open discussion. Her death has sparked an outpouring of grief and gratitude on social media, with many mourning the loss of a brave and influential figure who fought for liberty and justice.

The passage discusses the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, who are still considered second-class citizens after fleeing violence following the partition of India 70 years ago. These refugees, like Mangu Ram, a 82-year-old traditional healer, have been denied citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote in state elections. Despite never visiting Pakistan, they are classified as refugees and live in poverty due to their refugee status. The Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu nationalist party, has won a share of power in India's only Muslim-majority state, offering hope for the WPRs that their rights may be normalized. The WPRs, mainly from Punjab, have fallen foul of a pre-independence law granting citizenship only to those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. This has allowed around 35,000 Hindus fleeing Pakistan-controlled Kashmir since partition to be granted citizenship. The WPRs' cause is expected to be championed by the Bharatiya Janata Party, which has joined a Kashmir governing coalition for the first time.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer, following a £4 million offer made by the club. Chelsea aims to loan Muto to Vitesse Arnhem next season, but the 22-year-old seeks a club where he can play regularly and develop his skills. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane confirmed the offer, and Real Zaragoza coach Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut in 2013, believes Muto's intelligence and speed could make him a success at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto and acknowledges the role of commercial interests, such as their £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, in the club's transfer policy.

The passage praises Australia for changing its policy to select its best players regardless of them playing overseas, highlighting the need for England to follow suit. It argues that England coach Stuart Lancaster should be allowed to pick his best players, no matter where they play, to ensure the best chance of success in the World Cup. The passage provides examples of players who improved after moving abroad, such as Matt Giteau, Steffon Armitage, and Nick Abendanon, and emphasizes that selecting the best starting XV is crucial for a successful World Cup campaign.

The passage discusses the development of the Firechat app and the Greenstone gadget by Open Garden. Firechat, downloaded over five million times, allows off-the-grid chatting using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and a similar feature on Android, creating wireless mesh networks. These networks enable message and photo sharing without a mobile signal by connecting phones directly, up to 30 feet apart. Apple utilizes MCF for its AirDrop feature, and Firechat's messages are sent securely, with users able to send messages anonymously. Greenstone, an egg-shaped gadget, acts as a beacon or booster to extend the range of these mesh networks, overcoming the typical 200 feet limit. It is designed to improve communication in communities, neighborhoods, hospitals, or crowded events where traditional networks may fail. Currently, Greenstone works with Firechat at a range of about 20 feet and can store up to 1,000 recent messages. Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to design and sell Greenstone.

In a TED Talk, burlesque performer Lillian Bustle argues for embracing the word "fat" as an honest, body-positive description of one's physique, rejecting its use as a synonym for "ugly." She shares statistics on size discrimination in the workplace and the desire for thinness among young girls but highlights studies showing that increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater acceptance. Performing burlesque allows Lillian to showcase a "fat" body in a positive, glamorous way, aiming to change perceptions. Since her TED Talk's release on YouTube, she has received mostly positive feedback and stories of personal impact.

The passage discusses Theo Walcott's situation at Arsenal, where he has been frequently benched for most of the season. It mentions a photoshoot with Walcott and several of his Arsenal teammates, including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Özil, for the fashion house Lanvin, which has been the club's official tailor since 2013. The passage also notes that Walcott, who has been a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Barclays Premier League games, hopes to start a game soon. The context of the photoshoot is related to the upcoming FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30, where Arsenal's first-team stars will be dressed in similar attire.

The passage discusses an auction of Hollywood props and puppets from movies such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. The collection, created by make-up effects artist Rick Baker, is worth an estimated $746,100 and includes items like the alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, the two-face mask from Batman Forever, and the Grinch costume from the Jim Carrey film. The auction will take place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on PropStore.com on May 29. Over 400 items from more than 50 productions, including films like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker, will be available for auction.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, was killed in the French Alps when he became separated from his family while skiing. Carwyn fell over a 164 ft drop in dense woodland after entering the area on his own. His family described him as a "daring, outgoing, and determined" youngster whose death has left a "vast void" in their hearts. The boy's body was found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn was a skilled skier and snowboarder who had started skiing at the age of three. The family had been enjoying a happy ski holiday in Flaine before the tragic accident occurred.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, has spoken out about her two-year battle with anorexia and the pressures on young girls to be a size zero. At her lowest point, Laura was consuming just 100 calories a day and hiding food to make it look like she had eaten more. After collapsing due to starvation, she spent a week on a heart monitor in the hospital. She then received support from eating disorder organizations during her recovery process. Laura's experience highlights the serious mental health condition of anorexia nervosa, which affects around 725,000 people in the UK, with 10% suffering from anorexia.

Liverpool players, including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, unveiled the new home kit designed by US sports brand New Balance, which signed a record-breaking £300 million four-year kit deal to replace sister company Warrior. The players interacted with fans and discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. The new kit features a gingham design, a memorial flame and number 96 for the Hillsborough disaster victims, and an all-white branding.

The passage describes the creation of the largest high-definition map of dark matter by researchers at the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle. The map, which covers 0.4% of the sky, is the first in a series that aims to eventually provide a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. The map is based on data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES). Dark matter makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe and its effects can be observed through gravitational lensing. The ultimate goal of the survey is to understand the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be causing the expansion of the universe to speed up. The DES is set to map 12.5% of the entire sky, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy, and is expected to be completed by 2018.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven player Memphis Depay, who is 21 years old. United's manager, Louis van Gaal, is eager to make him one of his first signings in the summer. Van Gaal is familiar with Depay as he had selected him in the 23-man World Cup squad for Holland in 2014. Premier League rivals Tottenham had expressed interest in Depay the previous summer, but PSV rejected their £15 million offer. Now, Manchester United is in a strong position to sign the Dutch player, despite competition from other major European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and played for the Holland national team in the 2014 World Cup, scoring crucial goals.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side in the Youth Cup final. Tammy Abraham scored two volleys for Chelsea, while Dominic Solanke added a late goal to the scoreline. Manchester City's players, including Isaac Buckley-Ricketts and Brandon Barker, put up a brave fight but were unable to overcome Chelsea's strong performance. Both teams showcased their talented young players, with Chelsea's defense and midfield standing out as they managed to control the game and secure a commanding lead. userThe question is: 'What was the result of the match and who were the key players?'

The result of the match was a 3-1 lead for Chelsea going back to West London after a strong showing in Manchester. The key players for Chelsea were Tammy Abraham, who scored two volleys, and Dominic Solanke, who added a late goal to the scoreline. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts managed to bring the score level for a short time, but overall, Chelsea's strong performance led them to victory. userThe question is: 'What was the result of the match and who were the

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes that people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He does not consider same-sex marriage a constitutional right and thinks states should decide whether to allow it through political debate rather than court rulings. Despite his disagreement with same-sex marriage, Rubio stated he would attend the wedding of a family member or staffer he cared for. As a Catholic, he also believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has announced his run for president, and donors have already pledged monetary commitments for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who have embarked on a journey to travel the world by bicycle. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they set off to discover different parts of the planet in a slow and cost-effective manner. In their first year, they cycled nearly 7,000 miles, passing through 16 countries while spending less than three euros each per day. They rely on camping, hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and occasionally dumpster diving to keep their expenses low. Food is their main expense, costing 2.74 euros each per day. They plan to continue their journey across Asia, the Pacific, and the entire length of the American continent in the coming years.

A couple from Texas, who got married in 2012, claim that their photographer wrote racial slurs on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their wedding. The couple, who prefer to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly providing a photo booth that printed "poor n***** party" on the bottom of the pictures. They were not alerted about the photos until months after the event. The couple is suing the company under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. James Evans denies all allegations and stated that there is no evidence linking the company to the offensive caption. Mediation is scheduled, and if an agreement is not reached, the case is set for trial in July. The couple's lawyer states that they want an apology from James Evans at the very least.

England full-back Mike Brown is recovering from a concussion and is unsure when he will return to action for Harlequins. He is adopting a cautious approach to avoid an extended break. Brown was advised by medical professionals to be aware of concussion symptoms, which helped him make the decision to pull out of the Ireland game. Meanwhile, Northampton wing George North has been advised not to play again this season after suffering four concussions.

The passage suggests that smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples. Research indicates that Britons are having sex less often since the emergence of the internet, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Factors for this decline include the blending of public and private lives, constant email checking, and increased technological connectivity leading to busier lives. The boundaries between home, work, and the outside world have become blurred, resulting in less time spent with partners.
