The passage describes "Fist of Legend" as a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," which originally starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

In a tied lead at 16 under par, France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl share the top spot, while McIlroy and Thailand's Aphibarnrat are at 15 under par. McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, overcame early setbacks to card a third consecutive 67. He is currently focusing on playing within himself and aims for a low round in the upcoming day. Despite a past ankle injury that sidelined him for several tournaments, McIlroy is targeting a third Race to Dubai title, leading Danny Willett by a significant margin with three events left after the Turkish Open.

In the passage, Sheikh Ali Salman emphasizes the importance of meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, calling for the government to provide concrete solutions and engage in dialogue with the opposition. He highlights the division within the royal family, with Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa seen as a reformist and the Prime Minister as a hardliner opposed to concessions. Sheikh Salman acknowledges the loss of faith among young protesters in the opposition parties but believes working with reformists within the royal family is the way forward. He also discusses the seven-point plan that was interrupted by the intervention of Gulf Co-operation Council troops and expresses hope for clearer US policy under Secretary of State John Kerry. Sheikh Salman urges the UK government to publicly address the issue of human rights abuses in Bahrain and calls for the release of opposition leaders and activists sentenced on torture-derived evidence.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. He worked with leading orchestras globally and was a significant figure in the early-music movement. Hogwood established the AAM in 1973 and directed it across six continents for 30 years, during which the academy produced over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, which was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. He studied at Cambridge University and later worked as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. His contributions to historically informed music were widely acknowledged, and his legacy continues to influence the music world.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide cases, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. This represents half the figure from nine years ago, with only one case from 2015-16 remaining unresolved. The most common method of killing was with a sharp instrument, particularly a knife, involved in 26 of the 29 cases. 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. While the overall homicide rate has decreased, violent crime and sexual crime rates have increased, with a 27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasizes the need for continued efforts in education, enforcement, and supporting communities at risk of violent crime.

In a Premier League match, Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first win of the season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but the team failed to capitalize on numerous chances, conceding goals from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe. Despite being down a man, Bournemouth could not find an equalizer. Coach Howe acknowledged the team's struggle to score despite creating many chances and emphasized the importance of moving forward from such setbacks.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's stance on preventing migrant deaths at sea. He argues that the only way to stop these deaths is to "stop the boats," a policy that involves detaining migrants and taking them to offshore processing camps for resettlement. The New York Times has criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality." The paper also warned European leaders against adopting similar policies. While Australia has not responded to the editorial, Mr. Abbott maintains his position, citing the tragic image of Syrian child Alan Kurdi as a reason to stop the boats. Additionally, Mr. Abbott sparked controversy by comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis, a comparison criticized by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry as an unfortunate and unjust comparison to the systematic genocide committed by the Nazis. Mr. Abbott later clarified that he was not in the business of ranking evil but stood by his comments.

The passage describes the escalating conflict between the US and Russia over the situation in Aleppo, Syria. The US accuses Russia and the Syrian government of intensifying attacks against civilians, particularly in the city of Aleppo. In response, the US warned it would halt talks with Russia unless Moscow ceased bombing Aleppo. Russia regrets the US move and accuses the US of shifting blame for the collapse of a recent truce. The main trauma hospital in eastern Aleppo was hit in an air strike, and hundreds, including children, have died since the government forces aimed to take full control of the city after the truce lapsed. The US suspended its participation in bilateral talks with Russia, citing Russia's failure to uphold its commitments. Moscow denies involvement in the deadly aid convoy strike and criticizes the US for not fulfilling the agreements they worked out. The US also withdraws personnel intended for a joint US-Russian implementation center, but the two sides will continue discussing counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

The passage discusses a report by Policy Exchange, which suggests that selling high-value vacant homes could raise £4.5 billion a year, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. The report proposes the largest social house building program since the 1970s, which could give a boost to the economy. However, Labour disagrees with the idea of pushing out low-wage families from certain neighborhoods. The think tank's director, Neil O'Brien, argues that social housing would still exist in expensive areas but in lesser quantities, and that the overall number of people waiting for social housing could be reduced by 500,000 if implemented. The prime minister's official spokesperson says councils can already choose to do this and should use their social housing stock efficiently. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the idea, while critics argue that it would create new ghettos by pushing the least well-off out of expensive streets.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old man from Swansea, died last week amidst a measles epidemic that has reached 942 cases in the city. The cause of his death could not be determined through initial examination, and further tests are being conducted. Since the outbreak started in November, 83 people required hospital treatment. Colfer-Williams had been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital before developing a rash and seeing a GP, where he was diagnosed with measles. However, it is unclear how he contracted the disease, as no close family members, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have measles.

Vincent Hudson, a 54-year-old man from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense of assaulting a boy under 16 years old. The alleged attack reportedly occurred in 2001 and was reported to the police. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In a National League match, Guiseley and Gateshead ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute with a goal by Jake Lawlor, while Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wes York. Both teams had defensive moments, with Liam Hogan blocking a shot and Jonny Maxted making a save. The match saw several substitutions and a yellow card for Gus Mafuta and Simon Walton. Guiseley remained unbeaten in five matches, while Gateshead has not lost in nine.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to the delayed new stadium proposal at Ashton Vale. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced that the club will begin work after a shareholder meeting, with the project approved by Bristol City Council in November. The redevelopment, set to start in May, is contingent on signing a section 106 agreement and passing a six-week judicial review period by March.

The passage discusses Cuadrilla, a firm conducting shale gas drilling, also known as "fracking," which involves breaking shale rocks to release gas. After experiencing two small earthquakes near their drilling sites in Lancashire, they suspended operations to review data from the British Geological Survey (BGS). The BGS found that both tremors shared a similar location and mechanism. Fracking has been controversial in the US due to environmental concerns, but the UK's Commons energy select committee believes these can be mitigated with regulation and good practice. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution, and Cuadrilla is expected to decide on further actions after consulting with authorities and experts.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud and cleared of two other counts by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court. Carpenter, who has played in the city centre for over 30 years, was accused of misleading the public by playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015, seemingly collecting cash for the charity. However, Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and had received permission to display the banner as a tribute to the victims, not for fundraising purposes. Carpenter is known for his presence on match days at Anfield and will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, ending their run of seven games without a goal. Goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence secured the win, which moved Ipswich up to 14th place in the Championship. QPR's goalkeeper, Alex Smithies, contributed to two of Ipswich's goals through errors, but also made saves to prevent a more comprehensive victory. QPR's performance was disappointing, especially in attack, and they slipped to 15th place. Ipswich's manager, Mick McCarthy, praised his team's effort, while QPR's Ian Holloway criticized his team's mental toughness and defended his goalkeeper.

In the given passage, 23-year-old Wells performed impressively in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs with a strike rate of 138.66. He expresses enthusiasm about the club's direction, noting its focus on elite performance, which motivates the players to be part of it.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, achieved their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams led the team, with the front row and front five making over 70 tackles in the game. The Reds have seven upcoming matches against teams below them in the table, including a game against league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the recent success, coach Churcher believes there is still room for improvement, stating the Chinnor game was not a complete performance but a determined one. He emphasizes the need to build on this success to avoid wasting the previous weekend's efforts.

The passage describes the arrest of 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, in connection to the rape of a 74-year-old nun at a convent in Ranaghat town, India. Allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, Nazu was apprehended at a railway station in Kolkata after being identified from CCTV footage of the attack. This marks the sixth arrest in the case, with eight suspects identified in total, two of whom remain at large. The five previously arrested suspects have named Nazrul as the perpetrator of the rape. The incident has sparked outrage and protests across India. The attack also involved the theft of money from the convent school and the ransacking of the building.

The passage introduces an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. In the video, Opie discusses key factors that influence changes in consumer purchasing behavior, such as the introduction of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The interactive elements also examine the evolving ownership and ranking of major UK brands. The video is recommended to be viewed in full screen and provides additional resources for further reading.

A 71-year-old Sandyhills woman and a Stranraer woman were victims of two separate scams by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. The callers gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole money. Both incidents occurred within a week, with the Sandyhills incident on September 15 and the Stranraer incident seven days later. Police warn against giving remote access to computers or sharing banking details over the phone, as reputable businesses never request such information.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract with the third-placed Championship team, Featherstone, after departing from Swinton Lions. As the Scotland assistant coach, he will guide Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday, preceding the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praises Duffy as a fantastic coach and acknowledges his remarkable work at Swinton under challenging circumstances. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been succeeded at Swinton by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. They attended to a rider who had suffered head injuries and was severely cold due to being unconscious on wet sand. The rider was then treated and airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to allocate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve on the current system that relies on ground-based radars. This decision came in response to the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014, which exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The new system will use satellite tracking of planes through automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B), allowing real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who went missing at age five, was found living in Cleveland with his father, Bobby Hernandez, now 18. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity after he faced difficulties applying for college. His mother has been notified of his recovery, and his father is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected Bobby Hernandez of being responsible for Julian's disappearance in 2002.

The passage describes a fire that occurred at a site in Duncan Street on 2nd March, leading to disrupted train services and travel delays. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. Despite the firm being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective from 7th August. The site was operated by Asset and Land Group, and the company is required to remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, which are linked to the situation in Ukraine. The first bill aims to allow Russia to accept territories from a neighboring state, such as Crimea, if the local population wishes to join Russia. This bill is seen as a response to the crisis in Ukraine and the pro-Russian sentiments in Crimea. The second bill seeks to expedite the process of issuing Russian passports, particularly for Ukrainians, by removing certain requirements and reducing the time needed to obtain citizenship. This bill is aimed at supporting Russian-speaking Ukrainians, describing them as defenseless against the "brown threat," referring to World War Two fascists. The passage also mentions several Russian MPs and celebrities visiting Crimea, highlighting the significance of these bills for Russia.

The passage discusses the decline of the McLaren Formula 1 team, which has fallen from its past greatness. Despite having an impressive record with 182 grand prix wins and 12 drivers' world championships, the team has been struggling since 2013 due to issues with chassis design and Honda power-units. The partnership with Honda, which once brought them great success, is now facing challenges. The team's slump has been a cycle of triumph and decline throughout its history, with periods of domination followed by dips in performance. Current team boss Ron Dennis believes that success will return, and that McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance in F1. However, for now, belief in the team's potential for future success is all they have.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was found severely injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27th after being shot in the head and chest. He later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29, 29, and 32, have been arrested and are in police custody for questioning. Detectives believe the assailants waited outside the Phoenix Gym at the market for about an hour before the shooting. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that sped away from the scene and traveled through several roads. Det Ch Insp Bev Hyland also mentioned that some individuals captured on CCTV near the meat market have not yet come forward, potentially holding key information for the investigation.

The passage describes various ways to enjoy a spiritual Christmas online. Everyday Church Online offers virtual services for a global congregation, with people from 61 countries participating. Guardians of Ancora is a fantasy game with Bible-themed quests for children. Viral.de's digital nativity video has been viewed almost six million times, while the Churches Advertising Network's video has been viewed about 250,000 times. Next Manga has released the Manga Messiah in app and e-book form, with 33 languages available, aiming to share a message of hope with refugees. Social media platforms are also used by Christian groups to connect and share spiritual messages.

The eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is evaluating a proposal to convert over 250 hectares of common land into a circuit. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts provide conflicting views on the impact of the project on habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it hard to conclude the replacement land's equal value but does not oppose the development. A developers' ecology report suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity, while the Gwent Wildlife Trust disagrees. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend after the inquiry, and Welsh government ministers will make the final decision.

On April 1, Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 people suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed. The paper faced backlash from Chechen Muslim clerics, who accused it of insulting their faith and dignity, and called for retribution against journalists. Novaya Gazeta, fearing reprisals, urged Russian authorities to prevent actions inciting hatred towards journalists. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, stating that detainees were tortured at a prison near Argun. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there were no gay people in Chechnya. The situation raises concerns over human rights abuses and the potential involvement of influential clerics and TV presenters close to Kadyrov. The LGBT Network is assisting victims and may take legal action if the Russian authorities do not address the abuses.

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing have a symbiotic relationship where the former receives housing benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men, while the latter sources clients from London homeless charities. Both entities are legally operating, but their relationship has been criticized by a homeless group. Investing Solutions makes money by charging housing benefit for each person in a shared house, resulting in higher total benefit payouts than the rent passed on to landlords. Based in south London, Investing Solutions is one of the largest housing benefit recipients in the UK. The company focuses on providing housing to single homeless men over 35 but has been criticized for offering unsuitable accommodation. Wandsworth Council has paid the agency over £2.1 million.

In a well-contested game, London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 points for the British team. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters but was eventually overhauled by the Dutch guests in the last 10 minutes. The Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to lead 71-60 and held on to win despite the hosts' comeback in the last six minutes. Coach Prunty highlighted the importance of completing every play in the upcoming Eurobasket qualifying campaign, starting with a game in Hungary, and praised Gordon's performance, especially in the third quarter.

The passage discusses the upcoming boxing match between Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather, scheduled for August 16. McGregor, a former five-weight world champion, submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to wear 8 oz gloves for the fight, as opposed to the standard 10 oz gloves required for fights at 154 lbs. The NAC will debate the matter before announcing its decision. The fight has prompted criticism from major boxing personalities, but NAC executive director Bob Bennett approved the fight after studying a "litany of information" on McGregor, including his performance with Nate Diaz. McGregor will make his boxing debut in what could be the richest fight in history, facing the undefeated Mayweather, who will come out of retirement for the bout.

The passage provides a historical overview of Fleet Street, once the center of British journalism, and its eventual decline. It details the street's heyday when nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers had offices within a half-mile radius, and the atmosphere was filled with the sound of typewriters and the presence of journalists and printers frequenting local pubs. The passage also mentions the shift in the newspaper industry with the advent of television and social media, and the move of newspapers to other parts of London and adoption of new printing technology. It concludes with the closure of the Dundee-based Sunday Post's London office, marking the end of an era for Fleet Street journalism. The last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, reflect on their experiences and the historical significance of the street.

The passage discusses J.K. Rowling's experiences with online criticism and her response to it. Rowling, a famous woman on Twitter, has faced abusive comments, some of which crossed her personal line. She believes in standing up to bullies and has been open about the negative labels she's been called, such as "a traitor," for her political views. Despite this, she has also engaged in positive discussions with SNP supporters, finding common ground with many of them. Rowling made headlines for her donations to political campaigns, including £1 million to the No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and the same amount to the Labour party in 2008. The passage concludes with a mention of the SNP's success in the recent elections, securing 56 out of 59 seats in Scotland and becoming the third-largest party in the UK.

The passage discusses a study by the University of Edinburgh researchers that found children from deprived backgrounds were more likely to face police action and engage in violent acts compared to their better-off counterparts. Poverty was identified as a significant factor increasing the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors were considered. The study also found that gender was a powerful predictor of violence, with boys being more likely to engage in violent acts and girls from poorer backgrounds being more involved in violent crime. The research highlights a destructive dynamic where poverty increases the risks of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system inadvertently reproduces conditions where violence can flourish. Despite crime rates decreasing in Scotland, the most deprived communities continue to experience higher crime rates and are disproportionately affected by poverty and inequality.

In the early hours of Sunday, Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate. Robbie Walsh, charged with assault causing serious harm, has been remanded in custody and will appear in court next week. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Walsh and two others entered the estate looking for Mr. Haugh, leading to a fight where weapons were used. During the altercation, Haugh received a stab wound to his back. He was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. Police recovered knives, golf clubs, a knife handle, and a blood-stained blade at the scene. A judge noted tension in the Kilkee area due to the killing and remanded Walsh in custody until August 14.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted about Tom Elliott's past as a member of the UDR, suggesting he harassed and shot people. The tweet was deleted within an hour and Flanagan issued an apology admitting the tweet was untrue and without foundation. The High Court heard that Mr. Elliott, now an MP, has a clear MoD record. The insurance firm indemnifying MLAs has refused to cover Flanagan for compensation and costs, leading to a separate court action by Flanagan.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has increased its sweater production to 9,500 per week to meet demand, up from 7,500 last year. This growth is attributed to better-than-expected sales of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January and an increase in private label business. The company, established in 1874 and owned by Benny Hartop since November last year, sells in Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Managing Director Hartop credits the production increase to a surge in orders for both private label clients and their own brand, indicating a positive future for the company.

In December, Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Brian Wright, 55, admitted to hitting her with his VW Golf but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, blaming the setting sun for blinding him. The incident occurred as Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road during a red light. Wright's trial continues.

The passage describes a NATO exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose," which is focused on addressing the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat acting as the unseen enemy, U33. The USS Vicksburg is the command ship, and the task for the participating forces is to try to take out the command ship and an oil tanker. The passage highlights the difficulty of locating submarines, comparing it to looking for a needle in a haystack, and notes that Russia has a growing fleet of around 60 submarines, some of which can operate undetected for months. The exercise also introduces underwater unmanned vehicles or drones to help track the ocean, and emphasizes the importance of long-range maritime patrol aircraft in anti-submarine warfare. The lack of such aircraft in the UK's defense capabilities is highlighted as a significant gap, and the passage concludes that the search for Russian submarines will not be as easy as the hunt for U33.

The passage describes the ongoing ethnic violence and displacement in South Sudan, which has led to a massive influx of refugees into neighboring Uganda. Since the violence escalated in July, 340,000 people have fled into Uganda, making it the largest refugee crisis in the country. The conflict is primarily between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, with the ethnic targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, including killings, rapes, and thefts. Uganda is struggling to accommodate the nearly million refugees, with Bidi Bidi now being one of the largest refugee settlements in the world. Despite the challenges, Uganda is working with aid agencies to provide shelter, land, and resources for the refugees. The UN is urging the international community to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence, as it is resulting in the massacre of civilians from both sides.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer turned professional boxer since 2013, will compete against Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on November 12. With a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights, McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the £330 million investment by the coalition for new NHS facilities in England, including £33 million for Bridgwater Community Hospital. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The total cost is £33 million, with NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust covering the remaining balance. The project aims to improve patient well-being and healthcare delivery, with three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals already replaced in the past five years. The new hospital is planned for land at Bowers Lane, subject to planning permission, with a target completion date of autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre, while his black Mercedes car was nearby. The incident occurred around 13:35 GMT, and he was found with a gunshot wound to his chest. Despite being taken to Northern General hospital, he died from his injuries. Local residents identified him as part of a family that lives close to the shooting scene, where a family celebration was taking place. This shooting follows a series of recent shootings in Sheffield, though this incident is unusual as it occurred in the Upperthorpe area rather than the north of the city. Past shootings include one in Shiregreen where a 25-year-old was seriously injured, another in Southey Green where an elderly couple was shocked by shots fired through their living room window, and two separate incidents in High Green where shots were fired at houses in January.

The passage discusses the activities of various cyber groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, engage in hacking government servers, disrupting separatist funding, and monitoring CCTV systems in rebel-held areas. They use DDoS attacks to target websites and have hijacked network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Inform Napalm, a volunteer group, analyzed data obtained by the Ukrainian Cyber Troops and found evidence of Russian military involvement in Ukraine.

On the opposing side, the Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western group that aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans. They hacked several Ukrainian government websites during US Vice-President Joe Biden's visit and have disrupted electronic vote-counting systems and blocked President Petro Poroshenko's website. They also claim to have retrieved confidential documents from a member of Mr. Biden's team.

Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, focuses on publishing leaked documents from the Kremlin and has released information related to the conflict in Ukraine, such as emails from a key rebel commander. The passage concludes with a mention of BBC Monitoring, which reports and analy

In the passage, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick becomes emotional as MSPs Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and others bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5th election. McNeil warns Holyrood to learn from Westminster regarding accountability and scrutiny, while Salmond emphasizes the strength and diversity of Scotland and the importance of the parliament assuming greater responsibility for the governance of the country. Both McNeil and Salmond reflect on their time in the parliament and the need to serve the people of Scotland.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older individuals in residential care facilities within the country. She is gathering evidence from pensioners, their friends, and family members to understand their experiences with residential care. This information will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care practices and their impacts on older people. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment to determine the quality of life for older individuals in residential care. Additionally, her team will engage with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Despite some disappointment from Care Forum Wales regarding the lack of a care home representative on the main advisory panel, the review seeks to ensure that those responsible for services understand the realities of living in residential care and take necessary actions to improve the quality of life for older people in such care.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ended June 2016, despite a £1 million decrease in turnover to just over £100 million. The company attributed its growth to international sales increases in Europe and new markets. Harbro, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors, also operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, serving farming and rural communities with a variety of products. Despite the uncertain agricultural outlook and the challenges of the past 12-18 months, including Brexit's impact, the company remains confident in its position to face future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday. Another man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the case, treating the death as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, 6 ft tall, with grey collar-length hair, and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt. Police have urged anyone with information to contact them and are conducting additional patrols in the area.

The passage discusses David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, addressing the risks of a weakening global economy in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics. He highlights the delicate juncture the global economy is at, with a weakening baseline. This comes after China reported weaker-than-expected trade figures, showing a 25% drop in exports from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in its next release in April. The situation has ongoing consequences for businesses and industries relying on China's growth. The passage also mentions a related story about bulk shipping.

At a scrutiny meeting, Isle of Wight Council discussed issues with the new Cowes ferry, which has experienced breakdowns, groundings, and suspension due to training issues. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until July 2nd for recognition of the problems and ordered a project review by auditors. Businesses, like Valu-4-U in East Cowes, have suffered due to the ferry's issues, prompting discussions on compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged teething problems but stated that electrical issues have been fixed, ramp extensions will be made, and seamanship issues have been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. The incident resulted in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency for attractive and talented individuals, faced criticism for its discriminatory hiring practices. The agency advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, sparking backlash from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners. The EHRC called the ad "appalling" and "demeaning," while the Fawcett Society questioned the agency's adherence to equality legislation. Employment lawyer James Lynas deemed the ad "clearly unlawful," as it could be seen as code for discrimination against older women. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended their approach, citing the importance of first impressions and client preferences. However, the EHRC urged the agency to modernize its practices and adhere to the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on age, sex, race, religion, and other factors. Despite the controversy, Matching Models has a roster of high-profile clients, including MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods.

The passage describes a shooting incident at Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where a school employee, Mahesh, allegedly shot two students. The rare gun crime involved Mahesh entering 18-year-old Gautami's room and shooting her in the head, followed by shooting another student, Sirisha, who sustained severe injuries but is expected to survive. The motive for the shooting is unclear. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. Despite India's strict gun control laws, incidents like this occur, and the country has seen rare cases of gun violence in educational institutions, such as the 2007 shooting of a 14-year-old schoolboy by fellow students.

The passage discusses a report by advocacy group Glaad, which analyzed TV shows between June 2016 and May 2017. It found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with a notable increase in transgender characters from 7 to 16. However, Glaad expressed concern over the high number of lesbian and bisexual female characters who died or were killed off. The report also highlights a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's findings were based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series with confirmed casting. The organization's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledges progress but emphasizes that numbers only tell part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. His decision comes amidst a scandal involving millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC that appear to have vanished. Mackintosh, who was the leader of the borough council at the time of the loan to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, has denied any wrongdoing. Approximately £10.25 million of the loan is now missing, and the matter is under police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities." The football stand remains half-built. Mackintosh had previously stated his intention to stand for re-election but has now decided that it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

In April, Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards as he drove away from a party in Balch Springs, a suburb of Dallas. The incident occurred after police responded to reports of underage drinking at the party. Initially, authorities claimed the vehicle Jordan was in had reversed aggressively towards the officer, but footage later showed the car driving forward away from him. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with murder, facing 5 to 99 years in prison. He also faces four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official related to the other teenagers in the car, including two of Jordan's brothers. If convicted, Oliver would be the first Dallas County police officer since 1973 to be convicted of murder.

The passage discusses the decision of Melania Trump, the president-elect's wife, to move to Washington after their son Barron finishes school, rather than immediately with her husband. This decision has been met with mixed reactions on social media, with some criticizing it while others support her choice to prioritize her child's education. The passage also highlights that only two other First Ladies in US history did not reside in the White House during their husbands' tenure: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. The role of the First Lady is described as ceremonial, with some taking on additional public roles and initiatives. The passage mentions past examples of families adapting to life in the White House and balancing their children's needs with their public duties.

A 72-year-old man was found dead in a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on October 27. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been requested to examine the initial police response to the man's call before his death. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and is awaiting its results. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has ordered the investigation and will receive a report on Pirc's findings when completed.

The passage discusses a yellow wind warning issued for areas experiencing gusts up to 75 mph, particularly west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction of the wind may increase its impact, leading to potential disruptions to road and sea travel. Affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to stay closed on Monday for cleanup efforts.

In a game between the Giants and the Panthers, the score was back and forth with Dimmen tying it for the Panthers. Forney and Bohmback scored in the second period, making it 2-1. Radja and Desmarais added to the Panthers' lead, but Ling scored for Nottingham. The final score was Panthers leading 4-2. The teams will play again in a double-header match on Saturday night. Nottingham is leading the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton faced significant challenges, starting from the back and suffering a broken front wing on lap one, resulting in five pit stops. Despite his efforts, he now needs to overcome a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races to reclaim the lead from Nico Rosberg. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second, after colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, who managed to fight back to fifth place. The race was marked by an incident-packed opening, with multiple collisions on the first lap and the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Hamilton's recovery was hindered by damage to his car, leading to a challenging race and an uphill battle to catch up to Rosberg in the championship standings.

In an interview with Die Zeit, former German footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality, aiming to advance discussion of a topic ignored in German football. His former teammates and prominent figures in German football administration praised his courageous decision. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a significant moment in combating homophobia in football, with support coming from various corners, including Bayern Munich and German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman. This disclosure is hoped to encourage more openness about sexuality and break down the taboo in the football community.

The passage discusses the achievements of 34-year-old midfielder Sidwell, who has played 32 Championship matches this season, significantly contributing to Brighton's promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. With his contract expiring, Sidwell expresses his desire to sign a new deal, believing in the team's ability to stay in the Premier League. Brighton's win over Wigan has put them in a strong position to win the league title in the last two matches, leading by four points over Newcastle. Sidwell, who has experience playing in the Premier League with several clubs, credits his performance this season for potentially earning him a new contract.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, both teams scored one goal each, resulting in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool's Jamille Matt opened the scoring with a close-range finish after 12 minutes, while Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie equalized following a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Key moments included Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making impressive saves to deny Colchester from taking the lead, and Blackpool missing a clear chance to win the game when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner. The match ended with a red card for Colchester's Sean Murray for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The passage discusses a 29-year-old football player who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, during which the team was relegated from League One. The player, who has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, is expected to debut for the U's in an EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester United began the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington. The passage also directs readers to a dedicated page for the latest football transfers.

The passage discusses the initiative to create a permanent memorial to honor the UK's police force, particularly following PC Keith Palmer's murder outside the Houses of Parliament in March. The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5 million to construct the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire. The memorial will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty over the past 250 years. It will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, to be given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. Home Secretary Amber Rudd announced the government's commitment of £1 million towards the £4 million needed for the project. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019, aiming to recognize the vital contribution of policing to society and the courage and sacrifice of police officers and staff.

Manchester United remains 15 points ahead in the table with eight games left following a 1-0 victory against Sunderland. Manager Ferguson emphasizes focusing on upcoming games, noting the team's 25 wins out of 30 matches. They are 15 points ahead of Manchester City and have won 50 of 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games. The goal is to beat Chelsea's 95-point record from 2005. Ferguson plans changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries, including Wayne Rooney's potential availability.

In the passage, Google's Executive Chairman, Eric Schmidt, defends the company's tax payment practices, stating that they comply with legal requirements. He suggests that any changes in tax laws should be made by the government. The UK's tax system has been criticized for allowing multinational companies like Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland, to minimize tax payments in the UK. The Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee has proposed establishing a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, potentially leading to more transparency in corporate tax affairs. European Union leaders have agreed to combat tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt advocates for international tax reform, emphasizing that politicians, not companies, should set the rules for tax regulation.

The passage discusses the efforts of the NHS regulator, NHS Improvement, to reduce the agency bill for healthcare staff. In the previous year, £3.6 billion was spent on agency staff, and NHS Improvement aimed to decrease this by £1 billion by the end of the financial year, following the implementation of a cap in October that has saved £600 million so far. The cap restricts hospitals and other healthcare services from paying more than 55% above normal shift rates for staff, excluding senior managers. The goal is to lower the overall cost of agency staff and decrease reliance on them, as they are more expensive due to additional fees and employer costs. While progress is "promising," NHS Improvement stated that NHS trusts are still 10% short of their target, and it is unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has increased. The regulator plans to publish league tables of trust performance on agency spending and collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust, as some concerns exist about continued overpayments for agency work.

The Longford Town Centre, originally intended as a hub of commerce, now symbolizes the end of Ireland's economic boom. However, local traders like Matt O'Brien, who owns a clothing shop, are seeing signs of improvement. The main opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, suggesting that funds for water meters should be redirected to broadband improvement. They also argue that the Industrial Development Authority (IDA) is not effectively promoting Longford for foreign investment. The government counters by highlighting Center Parcs' planned tourism development, aiming to create 1,000 jobs upon its 2019 opening. Despite these positive signs, traders believe more efforts are needed to support local businesses, such as removing parking charges to attract more visitors. Overall, the midlands is beginning to experience economic recovery, but further action is required.

The passage describes an unspecified cricket competition that concludes on 29 May at a stadium. Eight teams participate, playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Key players include Warner, Kohli, and De Villiers, while leading wicket-takers are McClenaghan, Kumar, and Rahman. Four England players, namely Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen, are part of the tournament. The passage also lists fixtures and results for the competition.

The passage discusses the increase in the number of non-recyclable plastic carrier bags, which have become a significant environmental issue, ending up in dumps and rivers. In response, England is implementing a 5 p charge for plastic bags starting October, following the example of Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where such charges have led to a decrease in bag usage. The aim is to encourage reuse and reduce environmental impact.

The passage describes a day of severe weather in Wales, characterized by strong winds that led to various disruptions. A part of a school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, near Caernarfon, and hundreds of homes experienced power cuts. The day also saw train delays, speed restrictions, and lane restrictions on major bridges. A yellow 'be aware' warning for wind was in effect until midnight on Friday, coinciding with one of the busiest days of the festive season. High gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries canceled six fast sailings and transferred passengers to cruise ferry services due to adverse weather conditions. Arriva Trains Wales warned of speed restrictions and possible delays for services between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to expected high winds. Winds eased in the evening, and restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge were lifted. However, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to December 27 due to a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend.

The passage discusses Michael B. Jordan's excitement about joining the cast of the film "Black Panther," directed by Ryan Coogler, who also directed him in "Creed." Jordan looks forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, without revealing his role. The film, set to release in February 2018, will see Jordan and Nyong'o reuniting with their "Creed" director and Nyong'o reprising her role as Maz Kanata from "Star Wars: The Force Awakens."

The passage discusses the planned restoration of Alexandra Palace's theatre and BBC studios as part of a larger east wing restoration project. The theatre, founded in 1875, will be used for various performances and screenings. The BBC studios at the eastern end of the Palace will also be repaired and refurbished. The project aims to transform the Palace into a cultural destination, with the glazed east court becoming a space for public exhibitions. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8 million, Haringey Council £6.8 million, and Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the final £1 million by summer 2017, with a total cost of £26.6 million. The theatre, currently unused, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery. The goal is for the theatre to reopen in 2018.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, has earned 61 caps for the England national team since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner's decision to step away from the national team was made with common sense in mind, wishing success for the team under Sam Allardyce. Additionally, Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps starting in 2004, and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

In Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, Marcy Smith's house was engulfed in flames, caused by rubbish burned in the wood stove. Thanks to her son David's quick action in waking the family, they all escaped, though their house and pets perished. The fire alarm did not activate, and the family escaped with only their pyjamas. The community has supported them by donating clothes, shoes, and other items. David, who was on FaceTime with his father, is recognized for his crucial role in the family's survival.

The passage discusses the potential sale of a Premier League club, West Ham, with energy drinks giant Red Bull reportedly considering a £200 million offer. The club was previously bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for £105 million, and they now own over 85% of the club. West Ham has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but intends for the ownership to eventually pass to his and Gold's children.

The passage describes a non-Oscars red carpet event in Los Angeles, where fan-voted awards and promotions for upcoming summer blockbusters were featured. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking home best movie, while its star, Shailene Woodley, won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and Jennifer Lopez, among others. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, and clips from upcoming films were shown during the event.

The passage discusses the loan of 21-year-old footballer Cammy Smith from Aberdeen to Dundee United, where he has scored five goals this season. Smith, who made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances, is considered a valuable addition by St Mirren's boss Jack Ross. Describing Smith as a "good, mature boy," Ross believes he will fit well into the team and provide additional options in the attacking area. This comes as St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, is set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

The Northumberland County Council announced that, with the improvement in weather, their Jetpatcher machines can now effectively address potholes. The council aims to fill in 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will work on repairing rain-damaged drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six workers employed by Wood Group under a contract with EnQuest on the Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during planned shutdown activities. The exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), and EnQuest informed the HSE at the time. Although the level of exposure is believed to be unlikely to cause long-term harm, the workers have undergone and continue to undergo tests. In response to the incident, additional precautionary steps have been implemented to prevent such exposure in the future. The health and safety of employees is a top priority for both EnQuest and Wood Group, and they have conducted a joint investigation to reinforce health and safety procedures. The Unite union has criticized the treatment of the workers, calling for openness and transparency to improve offshore safety. The HSE was aware of the incident but did not conduct an investigation as it was not reportable under the RIDDOR system.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) acquired a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, which later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the returned bronze. The issue came to light in a 2012 court case against the dealer for trafficking antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the ACM decided to return the sculpture after the ASI submitted an official request in May. The museum acknowledged Aaron Freedman's confession regarding dealing in looted Indian antiquities and plans to take legal action for compensation due to the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake occurred 35 km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5 km, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake was felt in cities like Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. Italy is prone to earthquakes, as evidenced by a 2009 quake in L'Aquila that killed nearly 300 people. Aftershocks were felt across a large area, with power supplies cut in Garfagnana. Schools were evacuated as a precaution, and several buildings in urban areas experienced shaking. This quake followed two others in the same area last May that left over 20 people dead. The National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV) characterized the latest tremor as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow." Italy is still recovering from the L'Aquila earthquake, where six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of manslaughter for providing misleading information about the quake's likelihood.
The passage describes Austin Grant's excitement over a fruit that has grown on a plant in South Yorkshire, despite his initial doubts about the climate. The fruit is not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the game's release until 24 March, requiring additional weeks of testing and polish to enhance the game's quality. This decision is made in the best interests of the game and fans. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version promises even greater detail, with 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. The minimum specifications for running GTA V have been published. The game became the fastest-selling entertainment product upon its initial release in September 2013, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days.

The passage discusses the 76-year-old artist who won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" displayed at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. This was his first win after being shortlisted in 1991 and making the longlist three other times. "Squint (19)" is a challenging painting that depicts a leper squint, a hole in the side of medieval churches allowing undesirables to watch services. The artist mentioned that the relatively small size of the painting was one reason he entered it into the competition. The prize money will be spent on materials. The judge praised the piece for its subtle technique and minimal language, describing it as a tone poem that gradually reveals its meaning. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The passage describes simultaneous attacks on the offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, early on a Thursday. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, and both locations experienced shattered windows from gunfire. Firefighters extinguished a blaze at Yeni Safak, and police cordoned off the areas, finding numerous spent bullet casings. No casualties or claims of responsibility have been reported. The incidents follow a previous attack on the daily Hurriyet by pro-government protesters over alleged misquotation of President Erdogan.

The passage discusses a 24-year-old football player who was previously contracted with the Stags. Marcus Bignot's team, the Mariners, have negotiated a free transfer for him. The player had a loan period at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. He will officially join the Mariners on January 1st, marking Bignot's first signing for the team.

The passage discusses Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger's comments on England's national team manager Gareth Southgate and defender Hector Bellerin. Wenger praises Southgate's experience and observations, while addressing rumors about him taking the England manager position. He also expresses surprise at the speculation about Bellerin's future, stating that the 21-year-old's long-term future is with Arsenal, and confirms plans to extend his contract. Additionally, Wenger provides an update on midfielder Aaron Ramsey's injury, stating he will miss one or two more games.

A local man employed at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, according to Lincolnshire Police. The police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the probe.

The passage discusses a resolution to a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announces a new charter arrangement that will end the controversy. The RMT union had alleged that some workers on the freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will return contracted services to Serco Northlink from the following month. Currently, the freight vessels are operated by Seatruck, which is contracted by Serco Northlink. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined. The new charter basis will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage. This agreement aims to resolve the issue surrounding the freight vessels serving the Northern Isles, and the changes are set to come into force early next month, pending finalization of financial and regulatory details. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year £243 million Northern Isles contract in 2012 and operates three ferries and two cargo boats on a heavily subsidized route by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital following a confrontation at Rockley Park in Poole on 7 May, six days after the incident. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, leading to a fight. Mitchell and his mother, Samantha, 57, pleaded guilty to common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. The court will sentence them on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and the band Heatwave, died at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He contributed to hits such as "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights." His songs helped make Thriller the best-selling album of all time in the US. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. He was nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile and credited his father and Radio Luxembourg for influencing his songwriting.

The passage describes the discovery of ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, by a team including Swansea University's Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott. The team found over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" that have been concealed by rainforest. These sites are thought to be used sporadically for rituals, not as villages or for defense. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests the geoglyphs were built in a different environment than other known ritual sites. The research indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems free from human influence but were transformed by humans through selective planting of valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. This suggests a legacy of ancient "agroforestry" practices may still be present in some of Acre's remaining forests.

In the passage, Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 21st in the world, defeats world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open and is approaching the top 10 in rankings, admits to feeling tired and less vocal during the match. He attributes his fatigue to his success in Japan, the travel to and from the Qi Zhong Stadium outside Shanghai, and poor sleep. Kyrgios had previously faced controversy at the Shanghai Masters, where he was fined for a profanity-laced outburst and calling the tournament a "circus" the previous year.

The passage discusses the potential expansion of the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine to protect against head and neck cancers, in addition to its current use in preventing cervical cancer. Scientists and charities advocate for this change, emphasizing the rise in head and neck cancer cases, particularly affecting younger, non-smoking individuals, with three-quarters of those affected being men. The average age of onset is 55. Dr. Mererid Evans highlights the shift in demographics over the last decade. Charities such as Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are urging the Welsh government to expand the vaccination to include boys, a move they believe could significantly reduce the burden of these cancers. The current vaccination program in Wales has successfully vaccinated 85% of girls since its rollout in 2008. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering any changes to the HPV vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare form of blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, briefly attended a school prom in his honor before his death. He documented his life and treatment on social media through the page "Jak's Journey," which garnered over 28,000 likes. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude that touched many. He received a Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. After learning that his cancer had spread and no further treatment would be pursued, Jak and his family shared their story to raise funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

In a low-scoring match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda, with the only goal coming from Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The win sets Egypt up for a top spot decider against Ghana, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Earlier, Ghana had qualified for the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali. Despite a resilient Ugandan defense, Egypt managed to break through in the final moments, resulting in their victory. Uganda will face Mali in their final group game, with Mali needing a win and a favourable result from Ghana vs. Egypt to qualify.

Lancashire County Council plans to develop land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town without a station since 1956. The decision follows a study by Network Rail comparing potential sites. The proposed station aims to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The chosen location allows for future expansion and has good access to highways and connectivity to the town and surrounding areas. The council, which owns Glenburn Sports College, will now begin the process of acquiring the necessary land.
In a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered an elaborate grow house containing plants. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, both German citizens of Kurdish origin, handed himself in to authorities. The woman underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. The motive for the attack is unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. It analyzed 4,600 workers and compared full-time and part-time males with their female counterparts, debunking the "reticent female" theory. Men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The research also found no evidence that women avoided asking due to fear of upsetting their boss or stereotype adherence. The study, based on 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey data, suggests that some element of discrimination exists against women in pay rise negotiations. However, the study noted that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, indicating a potential change in negotiating behavior among younger generations.

The Oxford City Council has spent £60,000 in search of a new burial site but has not yet found a suitable location. Two cemeteries, in Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council is still exploring options but has run out of suitable land within Oxford due to various restrictions and conditions. Once the cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes would be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place from 19 to 22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, will introduce an augmented reality app for visitors. The app will allow users to access online information, videos, and band interviews by interacting with physical items like signs and posters on the festival site using their phones and tablets. This year's lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan aims to enhance visitor enjoyment and also enable global interaction, offering an updated festival experience leading up to and during the event.

The passage describes the tragic death of the 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, who collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse was treated by veterinary staff but was pronounced dead due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Although such incidents are rare, the British Horseracing Authority is committed to understanding the cause and prevention of such occurrences. Many Clouds had experienced post-race ataxia symptoms in the past, but not on the day of the race. The horse was known for winning the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described as the "horse of a lifetime" by trainer Oliver Sherwood. The passage emphasizes that Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues and raises questions about whether his tendency to overheat was linked to his death.

In the autumn of 2004, a 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton, then 34, in a Portsmouth garage, where Ayrton, who later changed her name to Davina, denied charges of rape. The case was considered unusual and challenging by Judge Ian Pearson, who remanded Ayrton into custody, likely to be held at a male prison in Winchester. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide the previous summer. The court heard that Ayrton raped the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage. The victim recalled shouting and swearing at Ayrton to stop, but her friends did not wake up. Ayrton spoke about her sexuality during the trial, stating she had not made physical changes or taken medication related to her gender identity.

In the passage, it is described that Serbian duo Novak Djokovic and Nenad Zimonjic lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in a Rio match. This loss occurred on the heels of Djokovic's elimination from the singles competition by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Notably, Djokovic, aged 29 and ranked world number one, had previously experienced a surprising third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July against American Sam Querrey. Despite this, he rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics. The passage concludes with an invitation to subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for a curated selection of news, features, and videos.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, with over 20 competitors from various countries including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants are restricted to using chainsaws for carving, creating figures of animals and people from logs. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, plans to defend his title and keep the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained during a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He anticipates a return to play before the Six Nations in February, with a possible comeback as early as the beginning of February. Webb is currently undergoing a preseason training regimen and plans to assess his progress week by week. Wales will start their Six Nations campaign against Ireland in Dublin on February 7. Webb, who has been capped 16 times by Wales, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other clubs. He expressed his loyalty to his home region, Ospreys, where he made his debut in 2007, and his desire to maintain his eligibility for the national team.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents intercepted two men attempting to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. One man fired at the agents and escaped, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was captured. Canadian citizen Nathan Hall was later arrested in British Columbia. The duo carried 58 lb (26 kg) of ecstasy, and a backpack contained a California driver's license with a false name. Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their alleged role in the smuggling operation. The three US detainees face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in counseling sessions for children affected by online abuse, with over 4,500 children assisted in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The actual number of victims is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have shared experiences of torment and abuse, leading to fear of attending school. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, warns that bullying can severely impact young lives, especially with the advent of cyberbullying that follows children beyond school. She urges adults, including parents and teachers, to intervene to protect victims, as bullying tends to escalate if left unchecked. The release of these findings coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is collaborating with various stakeholders to address the issue. The Alliance is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat bullying. The report includes testimonies from young people affected by bullying, highlighting the emotional distress it causes and seeking advice on coping mechanisms.

The passage discusses recent developments in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, focusing on the US response to a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction. The US decision to abstain from vetoing the resolution angered Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of aiding in drafting the resolution. The passage also covers the background of the settlements, stating that over 500,000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since the 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which are considered illegal under international law. In response to the resolution, Israel took several actions, including summoning ambassadors and recalling its ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal. The passage concludes with the postponement of a vote on authorizing new homes in settlements, requested by Netanyahu's office to avoid straining relations with Washington ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
