The passage discusses a plan by NHS Employers to reshape the 1.3 million-strong healthcare workforce to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and the increasing number of patients seeking care from GPs. The Nuffield Trust review suggests that nurses and other healthcare staff could take on more responsibilities with additional training, such as filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists. While there are potential benefits in terms of improved patient care and more rewarding roles for staff, concerns have been raised by unions about using this approach as a quick fix for NHS problems and the need for proper funding for training.

The passage describes a road closure on Lower Bristol Road in Bath due to a crash that occurred at 03:00 GMT near Rackfield Place. The A36 road closure, affecting commuters and bus services, was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the cause of the collision are ongoing. Although some First bus services have resumed normal schedules, full service recovery may take a few hours. The company expresses gratitude for public support and staff efforts in managing the situation.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the potential impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimates that the project could lead to the deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually as they migrate. TLP disputes these claims, arguing that NRW's figures are based on unrealistic scenarios and that their own computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species being killed. The £1.3 billion project is considered a test bed for future installations in other coastal locations. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, and the Welsh Government has expressed support for the project, awaiting the government's position. NRW maintains confidence in its evidence and its decision-making process.

The passage announces the creation of a new agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, aimed at supporting the "hugely important" agri-food industry, which employs nearly 100,000 people across various sectors. The initiative was announced by Enterprise, Trade, and Investment Minister Arlene Foster and is set to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). The new body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, will offer strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations, fostering collaboration within the sector. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomes the announcement but notes the need for better coordination of current marketing efforts and the potential implications for the work of other organizations.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to participate in planting 40,000 new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, a project organized by the Woodland Trust. This initiative is part of a four-year effort to plant millions of native UK trees to honor those who died in WW1. The goal is to create a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The project aims to promote wildlife, provide a space for reflection, and serve as a living memorial. The public is encouraged to get involved, with the Woodland Trust providing saplings and advising on appropriate footwear. The event is located about seven miles outside Derry city.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller addressing domestic violence and honor crime, featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The award ceremony took place at the start of North Yorkshire's annual crime writing festival. US author Sara Paretsky, known for creating detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career. Paretsky's work as a female crime writer and her creation of a strong female protagonist in VI Warshawski were noted as significant contributions to the genre.

In 2016, New Zealand cricketer Mitchell Santner broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire, which was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed disappointment, noting that Santner's participation would have been a bonus. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, will return to Worcestershire after the ICC Trophy in June. He is eager to make up for lost time and contribute with both bat and ball. In 2017, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for all formats of the game.

In 2008, Barry Pring, a 47-year-old British man, was killed by a speeding car with stolen license plates in Kiev while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had left him to retrieve a missing glove. The Exeter County Hall coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, concluded that Pring's death was an unlawful killing, noting the difficulty in investigating a case of death abroad. The inquest revealed that Ziuzina, 19 years younger than Pring, attempted to claim his assets shortly after his death and had a Ukrainian lover. The couple had met online and married quickly in 2007. Pring's family believes he was killed in a staged hit-and-run. The case remains active but is not actively pursued.

The passage discusses the story of Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside, UK, who requires experimental treatment unavailable in the UK for his illness. Charlie's mother, Sophie Fearns, explains that he needs to fly to Seattle, America, for further T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital, as his last transplant failed. The family was left heartbroken by this setback, and treatment options in the UK were exhausted after a third relapse in April. In an emotionally charged turn of events, an anonymous donor "selflessly" paid for Charlie's treatment, leaving the family ecstatic and overwhelmed. The donor's identity remains unknown, but the family is immensely grateful. Charlie's treatment will commence as soon as possible after receiving financial clearance from the hospital. His parents are expecting to learn the starting date next week.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system to enhance the security of its iCloud storage service, following the leak of celebrities' intimate photos. The new security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after entering their username and password. This prevents unauthorized access to iCloud and blocks any purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or App Store. Users can also use a 14-character recovery key if their trusted device is lost or stolen, but there is a risk of forgetting or losing the key. ElcomSoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged that Apple's changes make the technique he believed was used in the recent hacks no longer work. Prof. Alan Woodward suggests that two-factor authentication should be the default security option for companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google. Apple plans to encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage discusses a potential deal where actor and former non-league footballer Danny Wright may acquire a 20% stake in Billericay Football Club, becoming a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. Notably, the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mr. Ashley has been requested to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers at his Derbyshire company's warehouse, following a BBC investigation. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, has given Mr. Ashley until 21 March to respond. The BIS committee is concerned with the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. Despite being offered alternative dates for a meeting, Mr. Ashley has not accepted any, and the committee warns that it may take further action, including seeking House of Commons support, if he does not agree to attend. Sports Direct, which has previously committed to reviewing worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight, has not commented on the matter.

The passage discusses a report entitled "Putin. War," which was finished by the murdered opposition politician's colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin. The report, based on facts from Russian and foreign media, argues that President Vladimir Putin waged war in Ukraine for his own ends, detailing the human and economic cost of the conflict. It presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment aiding rebels in eastern Ukraine and suggests that Putin used the war to boost his failing popularity. The report faces challenges in publishing and distribution, and its impact remains uncertain.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found deceased at Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday due to head injuries. A 34-year-old man from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, was identified as the victim. South Yorkshire Police have arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield in connection with the case, and both remain in custody.

The passage discusses the tensions between the UK and Welsh governments regarding the devolution of powers post-Brexit. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, complains about not seeing the Article 50 letter before its publication and feels the devolved administrations have been treated with a lack of respect. The UK government aims to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK but has not clarified which powers will be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. Questions remain about the allocation of funds accompanying the devolved powers, with Carwyn Jones expressing concerns about the lack of funding after 2020. The identity of the powers the UK government wants to devolve remains unclear, and more details may be provided in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

In Newry's Nursery Drive and Parkhead area on Friday night, two cars were damaged during an incident involving attacks on PSNI officers. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his appall at these mindless attacks on both officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were carrying out their duties when they were attacked and urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was removed due to employee complaints and alleged misuse of funds. The board doesn't expect him to return and has filed documents detailing his inappropriate behavior, including sexual harassment and racial taunts. This behavior has led to a defamation lawsuit from Mr. Charney, and the company argues that his actions make it unlikely for him to be hired by any company, due to the risks to the company and its shareholders. Additionally, American Apparel has been granted a restraining order against Mr. Charney, preventing negative statements about the company and attempts to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between two teams, with coverage on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website. The teams previously faced off in Patras, Greece, where Greece won 92-64. Three members of the winning Greek team will be absent in the upcoming game at Copper Box, London, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expresses excitement and sees the game as crucial preparation for EuroBasket 2017. This event is Britain's only home game before participating in FIBA EuroBasket 2017, starting early September in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the game against Greece, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the early days of the iPhone, from its unveiling by Steve Jobs to its transformative impact on technology and daily life. Initially, the author was tasked with getting a piece to camera on the new iPhone, despite its unavailability for casual handling. Through a fortunate encounter with Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller, the author was able to briefly use the iPhone for a news piece, which led to some viewer complaints about BBC's coverage. The author defends the significance of the iPhone, comparing its potential impact to that of the Model T Ford. The smartphone is described as the key technology of the last decade, changing how over two billion people live and work, including the evolution of photography. The author acknowledges that there were cameras on phones before 2007, but Steve Jobs' genius was in creating an attractive user interface that encouraged more than just basic phone functions. The passage concludes by reflecting on the start of the mobile connected era in San Francisco and the ongoing advancements in technology, particularly by Amazon and Google with AI-imbued products.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, several cats have died after ingesting a toxic substance, with tests confirming all cats near Victor Avenue were affected. The most recent case was seven-month-old Meereen, whose death has left her owner, Adria Pearce, devastated. The RSPCA is unsure if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate, and Inspector Andy Bostock urges the public to store pesticides and chemicals safely, emphasizing the importance of preventing leaks and cleaning up spills properly, especially during the time of year when antifreeze use increases.

The passage describes the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is set to implement austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors, despite previously opposing them. Surprisingly, there are no mass protests against these measures. The reasons could be the calm before the announcement of the extent of concessions made by Alexis Tsipras for the new €86 billion bailout or the acceptance of the "there is no alternative" (TINA) approach after Greece's near-death experience in July. Despite not delivering an end to fiscal austerity, Tsipras remains popular. The new bailout's success depends on offering hope for better times ahead, which may require debt relief from Brussels and Berlin. Meanwhile, Greece faces a vicious economic squeeze, with the banking sector remaining partially closed, affecting businesses and the upcoming Christmas season.

In the passage, actor Ross Kemp announces his brief return to the TV show EastEnders as Grant Mitchell, following the approach to be part of Dame Barbara Windsor's final episodes as her character, Peggy, is set to be killed off. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006, considers it important for the Mitchell brothers to be reunited with their mother for the last time. Peggy's character reappeared to inform her eldest son Phil about her cancer returning, and she is set to die from the disease in emotional scenes to be aired in the spring. The return of the Mitchell brothers offers a chance to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden's acting prowess as they face the loss of their mother.

In the passage, Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon fatally stalked and attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately knew Harry was responsible when police informed them of her death. The trial revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice, and her parents shared their guilt over not recognizing the severity of the situation and not taking stronger action to protect her. Following the tragedy, Alice's parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, aiming to remember their daughter for her vibrant personality, rather than the tragic circumstances of her death. Dhillon, 26, denied murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The passage discusses the £18 billion Hinkley Point project in Somerset, which has been approved by French firm EDF, the primary financier. The project, however, still awaits the backing of the UK government, as Business Secretary Greg Clark plans to "consider carefully" before supporting it. EDF CEO Vincent de Rivaz has canceled a trip to Hinkley Point following Clark's comments. Critics of the project have raised concerns about environmental damage, potential escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments, with one-third of the cost being provided by Chinese investors. The UK government has launched a further review of the project after EDF's board voted to approve it. The Hinkley Point C is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement, but concerns about EDF's financial capacity and potential delays have arisen. Environmentalists have also expressed concerns about the project, calling for more investment in renewable energy sources such as offshore wind.

The passage discusses a newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales that includes a space for the name of the person with whom the spouse has committed adultery. Family lawyers argue that involving a third party adds conflict and complexity to the process. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name this person. The form's purpose is to make the legal process more user-friendly, but concerns exist that the inclusion of the space may lead people to fill it in, increasing conflict. Adultery was a reason for over 10% of the 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales in 2015.

The passage discusses concerns over the emphasis on environmental policies affecting commercial forestry in Wales. Britain is the third largest importer of wood, and while the Welsh government encourages forestry organizations to invest in woodland creation, there has been a loss of 16,000 hectares of commercial forest since 2001. The timber industry contributes over £450 million annually to the Welsh economy, but there is a conflict with promoting native, broadleaf species and enhancing access for walkers and bike riders. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development, but challenges include difficult-to-reach forests and bureaucratic barriers to creating new woodland areas.

In Coatbridge, a boy was severely injured when he was struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at around 16:40. Emergency services were dispatched to the scene, and the boy was subsequently transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. His current condition is reported to be serious.

The passage describes the honoring of Arctic Convoys veterans with Ushakov medals by defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. These convoys, consisting of vessels that traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II, faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The convoys were crucial as they provided weapons and ammunition that helped Russian soldiers defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The Medal of Ushakov is awarded to sailors who have shown courage in defending Russia or its interests. Initially, the Foreign Office did not allow the awarding of these medals to the British veterans, but later allowed an exception, with President Vladimir Putin presenting the first medals in 2013.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation reported delays in initiating offenders' unpaid work and numerous instances of offenders being excused for non-attendance. An offender was found to have completed only 16 hours of a 17-month sentence. The Ministry of Justice is addressing the report's recommendations. Offenders may receive 40-300 hours of unpaid work for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were assigned tasks such as garden maintenance, decorating, or litter-picking. The inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, outlining 15 recommendations for improvement, including better organization and matching work objectives to offenders' circumstances. The report highlighted issues with viewing unpaid work solely as punishment and called for urgent remedial action. The Ministry of Justice supports more effective rehabilitation and is implementing the report's recommendations.

The passage discusses a comedian who is accused of hypocrisy due to living in a luxury home while advocating for economic and political revolution to help the poor. The comedian has acknowledged the criticism, stating that he believes in personal change, including sharing wealth, but argues that systemic change is necessary for a meaningful impact. He accepts the label of "hypocrite" but emphasizes the need to address the issue of inequality.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, turned the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite this, his work sped up the process of human genomics. After publishing the human genome, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the organism Synthia. Dr. Venter's journey to becoming a scientist was unconventional; he initially struggled with academics, served in the Vietnam War, and later found his passion in research. His breakthrough came when he focused on messenger molecules (RNA) instead of the entire DNA blueprint, allowing him to sequence genes at unprecedented rates. He faced criticism and failed funding but eventually founded Celera Genomics, completing the human genome project in three years. His work on synthetic life forms and oceanic microbe collection has the potential to create a new industrial revolution, helping wean off oil and reverse environmental damage.

The passage discusses a study by England's School Food Trust, which found that 4 out of 5 children who ate school lunches in England tried new foods at school that they hadn't at home. Consequently, half of the parents surveyed reported their children requesting these new foods be prepared at home. The study, involving 1,000 parents, identified carrots, sweetcorn, and peas as the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less favored. The research was prompted by a Mumsnet survey suggesting some parents opted for packed lunches due to children's perceived fussiness. School Food Trust Chairman Rob Rees and Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton both highlighted the role of school meals in introducing children to a variety of foods and promoting healthier eating habits. The study also noted that 40% of primary school children in England and about 46% in Scotland eat school lunches, with school meals now adhering to strict nutritional guidelines. The survey was conducted online among parents with children aged 4-17 years old.

The passage provides a summary of the football career of Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish player participating in Euro 2016. He began his professional career with Real Madrid, where he played for four seasons before moving to Juventus in 2014 for a reported fee of up to 30 million euros. Real Madrid retained an option to buy him back. Morata was also a target for Arsenal and Chelsea. During his time at Juventus, he scored 27 goals, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals, winning with Real Madrid in 2014 and scoring in Juventus' defeat to Barcelona in 2015. Morata started his football journey at Real Madrid, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013 after spending four seasons at the club before moving to Celtic. He made 51 appearances during his second spell at Forest. Since his release in May, he has been without a team. Wilson has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The passage discusses the disposal of Tesco's loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. The deal involves transferring around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees to the new business, with Tesco loaning the new business £80 million. Fresh & Easy operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, and has been losing money since its opening in 2007. It is understood that the remaining 50 shops will be closed. The disposal will cost Tesco £150 million, but part of that is a loan that may be paid back. If Yucaipa is successful in making the business profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. This move is described as an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market" by Tesco.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it and is now focused on competing in the 2016 Rio Olympics, aiming for a medal. Initially, he considered representing France in the martial arts competition. The passage also mentions a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the European range covered approximately 375 sq km, with Mont Blanc and its surrounding mountains being part of this area. By the late 2000s, this area had decreased to about 275 sq km due to glacier retreat. Research on this topic was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, which is the world's largest annual gathering of Earth scientists. The retreat of glaciers is not uniform across the French Alps; the most significant losses have been observed in the southern sectors, such as the Belledonne Massif, where glaciers have almost disappeared, and the Ecrins Massif, where the retreat is more than three times stronger than in the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern region, including the biggest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has experienced less significant retreat. The glacier retreat is attributed to the lower elevation of the southern mountains and different climatic conditions, with more precipitation and cloud cover in the north. Efforts to assess and monitor glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region, with Swiss researchers also

The passage discusses the Scottish women's national football team's efforts to qualify for the finals of an unspecified tournament, currently unbeaten and top of their group. Captain, Leeanne Evans, expresses her desire to avoid another play-off loss and qualify for a major competition. The team's match against Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland at number 20 in the world, is highlighted as crucial, with the outcome potentially deciding the group winner. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically, as the best six of the eight group runners-up also qualify. Evans and other Scottish players share their experiences playing in top leagues abroad, such as the women's Bundesliga, and believe that this exposure benefits the national team.

Stuart Campbell, the creator of the Wings Over Scotland blog, was arrested in the west of England due to allegations of online harassment made by a woman in south London over a two-year period. The harassment reportedly involved some tweets, which Campbell claims were not threatening. He has been released on bail and is due to appear in court in mid-September. Campbell is a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and has used his blog to support the cause since its launch in 2011.

PETA proposes replacing Skegness's mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish to promote an animal-friendly image, suggesting the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original mascot was created in 1908 for the Great Northern Railway to attract visitors to the Lincolnshire resort with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." Dawn Carr of PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman symbolizes cruelty to sea animals. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, believes the mascot is widely loved and does not promote animal cruelty, indicating that there may not be much support for a change. The suggestion will be considered by the council, but Macey expresses skepticism about the need for a change.

In a rugby match, Scotland dominated against Georgia, scoring six tries and leading throughout the game. Scotland's Tommy Seymour, Stuart Hogg, Sean Maitland, and Hamish Watson scored tries, while Georgia's Vasil Lobzhanidze scored both of his team's tries. Scotland's Greig Laidlaw converted five of the six tries and added a penalty. Georgia's Merab Kvirikashvili landed a penalty and a conversion. Scotland's strong performance led to a 45-16 victory, with the team showcasing their ability to both maintain possession and execute counter-attacks.

In a rugby match, Tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Bridge helped Widnes lead 14-6 at half-time, with Flynn scoring against his parent club. Flynn and another try in the second half made it 38-12. Despite three Castleford tries, Widnes held on for victory, moving above Wakefield into seventh place. Castleford, now in sixth, suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti national, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a US review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat." Al-Odah had been detained since 2002, following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Al-Odah's release, the first since May, reduces the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility was opened in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, and President Barack Obama has pledged to shut it down. Upon release, al-Odah will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait, as per the release terms.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was observed with services at Hyde Park Corner, Westminster Abbey, and the Cenotaph in London. Thousands attended, including expatriates and visitors, with parades and wreath-layings. The event marked the first time Anzac Day was commemorated in London in 1916, following the Gallipoli landings. The day serves as a moment of reflection on the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand soldiers in all wars, with participants including veterans, service personnel, and their families. The Gallipoli campaign in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of World War One, aiming to remove the Ottoman Empire from the conflict.

Clarkson, aged 30, has joined Premiership team St Mirren for a second time and may debut in the Championship against Alloa. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has maintained his fitness. Clarkson expressed his readiness to play and aims to contribute to St Mirren's progress in the table. With international experience and nearly 400 senior appearances, his previous teams include Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of bottom side Alloa.

The passage discusses the sale of the turkey firm Bernard Matthews to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. There were initial concerns about the pension scheme for existing workers, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that after productive talks, it was guaranteed that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, which was closed in 2004, will not be affected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements would continue. Mr. Harley met with Boparan representatives, who expressed the new owner's intention to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The passage discusses issues surrounding a new ferry vessel at Cowes, where the council leader, Dave Stewart, announced free crossing until July 2nd to acknowledge the problems and seek feedback. The council has ordered a project review by auditors due to a frustrating and disappointing start, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension due to training issues. Local businesses, like Angie Booth's Valu-4-U, are suffering significant losses, prompting questions about compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledges teething problems but believes they are manageable, with electrical issues fixed, ramp extensions authorized for vehicles, and seamanship grounding issues resolved.

The passage discusses the UK fishing industry's perspective on Brexit, highlighting the potential opportunities and challenges. Fishing communities, which had previously voted to leave the EU, see Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation like Norway. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee report warns that the industry might be a low priority in Brexit negotiations and that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in its waters as part of an overall deal. The report also emphasizes the need for continued market access, retention of many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), and adherence to international obligations for cooperation with neighboring states. While some in the industry argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities, such as new quotas that signal a positive future, others caution against potential complications arising from the dissolution of the CFP framework, which treated the UK as a single entity. The government aims to ensure maximum freedom for British companies to trade within the single market while reviewing fisheries management for sustainable practices.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and removed from the General Teaching Council Scotland register after a hearing. The court found his conduct "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher and noted a pattern of behavior over a lengthy period. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, was prohibited from re-registering for two years and deemed unfit to teach.

The passage describes a fire that occurred at a site in Duncan Street on 2nd March, leading to disrupted train services and travel delays. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. Despite the firm being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective from 7th August. The site was operated by Asset and Land Group, and the fire's cause remains undetermined. The EA emphasized that the company must remove all waste from the site.

Syria faces challenges in complying with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, having missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad attributes this to attacks on weapon shipments and the ongoing war situation. He rejects US criticism over the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, claiming to be defending against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have taken control of Aleppo's central prison, while the US expresses concern over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan for chemical weapons removal. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons is overseeing the operation, which has been slowed by security concerns. Syria aims to complete the transfer of chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March, as agreed upon.

England secured a series level at Old Trafford with a significant victory against Pakistan, marking their second biggest win over the team in terms of runs. The match showcased exceptional cricket from England's perspective, with Joe Root being named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Root's promotion to number three in the series proved successful, as he demonstrated responsibility and control in his batting. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's extraordinary skills and beautiful gameplay. Despite some initial setbacks, Root's focused and disciplined approach impressed coach Trevor Bayliss and former player Michael Vaughan. Pakistan struggled throughout the match, with only their captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests of the four-match series. Misbah acknowledged the team's disappointment and lack of confidence, but remained hopeful for improvement through hard work and mental strength.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older individuals in residential care facilities within the country. She is seeking firsthand accounts from pensioners, their friends, and family members to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both positive and negative aspects of care, with a focus on the impact poor care can have on the elderly. The review will assess various factors, including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the environment of care homes to determine the overall quality of life for older people in residential care. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's overall goals, they express disappointment that no care home representatives are included in the main advisory panel, suggesting a missed opportunity for partnership and engagement.

The passage discusses the appointment of Paul Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder, as the new manager at Aberdeen following a comprehensive selection process led by boss Derek McInnes. Sheerin, who has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, replaces Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Despite Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two at the end of the 2013-14 season, Sheerin's achievements include guiding the team to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011. With a playing career that included stints at several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, Sheerin transitioned into coaching after his on-field career and won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. The transition to Aberdeen was facilitated with the cooperation of Arbroath chairman John Christison, who understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.

Curtis and Paul Williams will temporarily lead Swansea City after Bob Bradley's dismissal, with the team aiming to appoint ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the new boss. The team faces challenges in avoiding relegation, as the Championship has become stronger and returning to the Premier League could be difficult. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, have lost their "Swansea Way" due to frequent management changes and player departures. However, the current squad is believed to be capable of staying up, and new signings are reminded of the club's history and the importance of staying in the top division for the area.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, turned the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite this, his work sped up the process of human genomics. He then focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the organism Synthia. Born in 1946, Dr. Venter was inspired to become a doctor after serving in the Vietnam conflict. He excelled in research during his medical training and became involved in molecular biology. His breakthrough came when he focused on messenger molecules (RNA) instead of the entire DNA blueprint, allowing him to sequence genes at unprecedented rates. This led to the complete genome of Haemophilus influenzae in 1995 and the formation of Celera Genomics in 1998. The company completed the human genetic code in three years, competing with the public project. Dr. Venter's unconventional approach and financial success allowed him to pursue his research independently. In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute, which aimed to create synthetic life and study oceanic microbes. Dr. Venter's synthetic life breakthrough has the potential to create a new

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in the UK are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The trust suggests creating thousands of new apprenticeships to boost the economy and improve job prospects for young people. Currently, in England, only 20% of employers offer apprenticeships, while in Germany, over 50% do. The study found that of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England each year, fewer than 200,000 are at the respected level three, equivalent to A-levels. The report calls for the expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, primarily at level three or higher. The Department for Education acknowledges the need for reform, stating that they are working to "drive up standards" in apprenticeships.

In the passage, British Paralympian Sarah Storey wins a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, securing her 22nd Paralympic medal, making her Britain's most decorated female Paralympian. She has won 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics, including four golds at the 2012 London Games. Storey, who started her career in swimming with six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, switched to cycling in 2005 and aims for further success at the upcoming Rio de Janeiro Paralympics.

The passage discusses the financial struggles of the football club Hereford United, which led to their expulsion from the Football Conference. The club faced a debt of £148,000 to their football creditors and failed to meet multiple extended deadlines set by the Conference. Despite efforts from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club and clear their debts, they were not the preferred option. The club's financial issues worsened due to falling gates, with the average attendance for the 2013-14 season being less than half of what it was in League Two five years prior. Consequently, Chester, who had been relegated, were reinstated as a Conference Premier club, while Hayes & Yeading remained in Conference South.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has earned 61 caps for the England national team since his debut in 2009, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships, though only playing three minutes at Euro 2016. He announced his decision, citing a need for common sense. Milner, who holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps starting in 2004, scored his sole international goal in England's 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. Known for his contributions to the early-music movement, Hogwood worked with leading orchestras worldwide and made over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. After studying keyboard at Cambridge University and later with esteemed musicians, Hogwood held positions as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard University, University of Cambridge, and Cornell University. Hogwood's legacy is celebrated by those who knew and worked with him, with many describing his generosity, influence on the historically informed music movement, and his contributions to the development of the AAM.

The passage describes the struggles of a family from Northern Ireland dealing with the education system for their unnamed son, who has special needs. Due to his inability to cope in mainstream schooling, the parents removed him in June and sought a place at a special school, but faced delays as all nearby schools were full. The boy feels isolated and misses social interaction. Recently, a potential solution emerged with the hiring of an extra classroom assistant at a local special school, with the possibility of the boy starting in the next few weeks. However, the mother is concerned about the over-subscribed special needs schools and fears similar issues for other families. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland, with efforts to ensure availability starting from 2016, but declined to comment on individual cases due to privacy rights.

The passage discusses the potential takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) and its implications for the fellow tenants, Newport County. The WRU plans to turn Rodney Parade into a rugby-only venue, which conflicts with Newport County's lease that allows them to use the ground as their home field until 2023. The WRU's takeover will be voted on in early May, and the outcome will affect the future of Newport County and their lease agreement. Additionally, the WRU intends to install an artificial surface at the stadium, which goes against Football League rules. On a separate note, Newport County is currently two points away from securing their League Two status, which would be crucial for the team and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the experiences of an individual who was a child soldier during Sierra Leone's civil war and later became involved in combating the Ebola virus in the country. The person was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels at age 15, trained to use a gun, and coerced into committing atrocities. After escaping and eventually finding support through a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, the individual turned his life around, focusing on education and community support. During the Ebola crisis in 2014, he and his team educated over 10,000 people about the virus, supported communities with food and supplies, and established an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives. The individual now works to invest in young people, believing they have the power to change the world. The passage also provides statistics on Ebola deaths in West Africa, with Sierra Leone experiencing 4,808 confirmed, probable, and suspected cases.

The passage discusses the potential auction of approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs due to the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign, launched in September, reached its target within a month, preventing the sale. Administrators Begbies Traynor announced that the collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, followed by a loan to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum's collection was at risk of being sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund after the museum inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill when the firm collapsed in 2009. Alison Wedgwood and Tristram Hunt MP expressed their relief and excitement over the successful fundraising campaign, highlighting the importance of the collection to Britain's cultural development and national identity.

The passage discusses a potential deal where actor and former non-league footballer Danny Dyer might acquire a 20% stake in Billericay Town Football Club, making him a club director. The club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points away from a play-off spot. Billericay was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week in the club. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, both teams scored one goal each, ending in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool's Jamille Matt opened the scoring with a close-range finish after 12 minutes, while Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie equalized following a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Key moments included Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe's impressive saves and a red card for Colchester's Sean Murray for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time. The match concluded with both teams recording a point each.

The passage discusses the proposed transformation of the disused Fawley power station's chimney into the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. This would be part of a £1 billion "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside developers, featuring a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, which closed in 2013, was commissioned in 1971 and could power one million homes. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016. The developers plan to preserve the chimney as a signature piece, aiming to start building in 2018, following an outline planning permission application later that year.

In the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old cyclist took bronze in the men's scratch race, while the women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats. The men's team pursuit secured a silver medal, and Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round. The young squad showed promise, with a positive outlook on their progress leading up to Tokyo 2020.

In the passage, actor Ross Kemp announces his brief return to the TV show EastEnders as Grant Mitchell, following the news of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy, being killed off. Kemp could not turn down the opportunity to be part of Peggy's final episodes, as he is a close friend of Barbara. Peggy's character returned to inform her son Phil about her cancer's return, and she is set to die from the disease in emotional scenes. Kemp's return will bring the Mitchell family together for the last time, reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother. Grant Mitchell is considered an EastEnders legend, and the show's executive producer, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, is excited to see the brothers face losing their mother and reuniting on-screen.

In a crucial Premier League match, Sadio Mane's quick double within 138 seconds led to a disappointing result for second-placed Tottenham at Anfield. Spurs' poor performance raised concerns about their ability to compete for the league title, especially with Chelsea potentially extending their lead to 12 points if they win against Burnley. Manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed his team's lack of readiness for the pressure of the Premier League, noting their poor away record since September. Critics, like Danny Murphy, pointed to Tottenham's defensive issues and suggested they need to improve their away game quickly.

In the recent elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP's decline was further emphasized by losses in key northern states and control of Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP held on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's historic gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP only performing well in the south-east and oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Buhari. The elections were relatively peaceful compared to previous years, indicating progress in Nigeria's democracy. The PDP, which was in power for 16 years, will need to undergo introspection and rebuilding under a new leader.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place from 19 to 22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, will introduce an augmented reality app for visitors. The app will allow users to access online information, videos, and band interviews by interacting with signs and posters on the festival site using their phones and tablets. This year's lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app's potential to enhance the festival experience both on-site and globally, enabling people worldwide to engage with the event, access real-time updates, purchase tickets, and experience the festival's unique atmosphere remotely.

The passage discusses the situation in several Birmingham schools that have been rated inadequate by Ofsted, an education watchdog. Park View and Nansen Primary schools' funding agreements are to be terminated, and Park View Educational Trust may lose control of these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School have been warned that they could lose funding if concerns are not addressed. The schools have faced issues such as parents undermining head teachers' authority and promoting a narrow, faith-based ideology. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw mentioned a culture of fear and intimidation in these schools. The Education Secretary, Lord Nash, has issued letters detailing concerns and listing actions the schools must take to improve. Some parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and pushing their own agendas.

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, is accused of gross negligence manslaughter for allegedly failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution claims Vinnie's death was preventable and that Ms. Rose's conduct was "criminal" as it fell far below the expected standard for a competent optometrist. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg set up meetings between a woman and a man from an adult website, filming their sexual encounters and sending explicit content to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was found guilty of coercing the woman into sexual activities, intentionally causing her family to view sexual images, and threatening behavior. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was placed on the sex offenders register and had his case remitted to the High Court due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge mentioned the need for a sentence reflecting society's abhorrence at his conduct, while defense counsel highlighted the shock Weatherhogg experienced upon being placed on remand.

In a cricket match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with contributions from Thompson (56), Wilson (41* no), and Porterfield (39). However, this was not enough as Afghanistan reached 171-4 with Shenwari (56) and Shahzad (47) leading the chase. The teams play again in the second T20 at the same venue. Ireland lost Stirling for a duck early on, but Thompson and Porterfield stabilized before Wilson's contribution. Shahzad and Tarakai's opening stand of 51 helped Afghanistan win. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the best bowling figures, but Ireland's Porterfield felt they could have scored 15 more for a potential 180. The absence of Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was a setback for Ireland, with him expected to return for the ODI series starting on 15th March.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Neymar's transfer to Barcelona, with the club paying £48.6m for the Santos striker. However, it is alleged that the actual cost, including other contracts, was far greater, amounting to £106.8m when considering fees, wages, and taxes. Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money, but the club insists no tax-related crime occurred. In response, Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to defend their reputation. The case's status remains uncertain, while Neymar has scored goals in both league and Champions League matches for Barcelona.

The passage discusses the investigation into the murder of two British tourists, David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, whose bodies were found on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand, on September 15. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, are in custody and have allegedly confessed to the killings. UK Metropolitan Police officers collaborated with Thai police to review the investigation. The UK detectives will compile a report and update the victims' families on their findings. The suspects face charges including conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if convicted. However, the UK Foreign Office has raised concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of the suspects' mistreatment.

The passage discusses the Scottish women's national football team's efforts to qualify for the finals of a major competition. The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to host Iceland, ranked one place above them at number 20 in the world, at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would nearly guarantee their place in the finals, which are to be held in the Netherlands. The team, including player Leeanne Evans, aims to avoid the heartbreak of previous playoff losses and is taking each step cautiously. The outcome of the match against Iceland and the return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20th is likely to determine the group winner. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify without needing a playoff, as the best six of the eight group runners-up will also qualify automatically. The team benefits from having players, including Evans, who compete outside of Scotland in top leagues around the world, bringing different skills and experiences to the national team.

Apple is implementing a new security measure to prevent the theft of intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud by using third-party software. The action aims to stop the tool from infiltrating Apple's internet storage service. The security facility remains optional, but experts suggest making it a default option. The process introduces an extra step after an account holder enters their username and password on a new device, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone number or via the Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or App Store is denied. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Previously, the two-step verification system did not apply to Apple's backup service, allowing cyber-thieves to download complete backups of users' data. Apple is now encouraging people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

In the May election, UKIP, which won, spent £2,956,737, the Tories spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. These figures cover the campaign period until polling day. UKIP's spending was 68 p per vote, Labour's 26 p, the Conservatives' 79 p, and the Lib Dems' £1.45 per vote. The Green Party, fourth, spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372, making the total spending of the six highest-spending parties £9,347,087. All but Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

The passage discusses two football player transfers: Centre-back Anderson, 27, moves from Barrow to a National League rival, potentially playing against his old club on February 18. His transfer was facilitated by cancelling his Barrow contract by mutual consent. Anderson has experience playing in Italy, Aldershot, and Exeter. Meanwhile, striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, former Port Vale manager. Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move pending international clearance. Nicholson highlights Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger to succeed. The Gulls, currently in a precarious position four points above the relegation zone and with only one win in their last six games, are hoping these transfers will improve their performance.

The passage describes the tragic death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, who collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse was treated by veterinary staff but was pronounced dead shortly after. The cause of death was determined to be a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Despite this incident, episodes like this are considered rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across various disciplines of sports horses. The British Horseracing Authority is committed to understanding the cause of such incidents and exploring ways to prevent them. Notably, Many Clouds had experienced post-race ataxia symptoms in the past, but not on the day of the race. The horse was a significant achievement for trainer Oliver Sherwood, having previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

In the passage, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick becomes emotional as MSPs Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond give their farewell speeches before standing down ahead of the May 5th election. McNeil warns Holyrood to learn from Westminster regarding accountability and scrutiny, while Salmond reflects on the diverse yet unified nature of Scotland and the importance of the parliament assuming greater responsibility for its governance. Salmond also expresses his belief that the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill does not fulfill the promises made during the referendum campaign. Both McNeil and Salmond are commended for their contributions to the parliament and Scotland.

The passage discusses an upcoming live-action adaptation of the 1991 animated film. It reveals that Emma Watson will play Belle, with Kevin Kline as her father Maurice. The roles of Mrs. Potts, the Beast, Gaston, and LeFou are to be played by Dan Stevens, Luke Evans, and Josh Gad, respectively. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set to begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured, at a meeting with victims' relatives. Last year, new inquests determined the fans were unlawfully killed, and in January, evidence files on 23 suspects were referred to the CPS. Out of these, 15 relate to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes during an FA Cup semi-final, and 8 concern the Independent Police Complaints Commission's probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police following the incident. Relatives will be informed of the decisions in a private meeting, and the Hillsborough Family Support Group chairwoman, Margaret Aspinall, expresses the families' determination for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has recently experienced multiple incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, leading to concerns about contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, within the facility. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issue and is working to enhance security measures to address it. A local resident has reported witnessing such incidents four times in two weeks and the prison is considering organizing a meeting to discuss response strategies. The former inmate also claimed that drones are used to deliver contraband directly to prison windows, though the Ministry of Justice denies evidence of drone usage at Chelmsford. New laws now allow for up to two years in prison for individuals who smuggle packages over prison walls.

Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, stands trial at Luton Crown Court for allegedly causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, outside Bedford Road Lower School in December, while she was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road. Wright admits to hitting Blackburn but claims he was blinded by the setting sun, preventing him from seeing the red traffic light. The trial continues.

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir, who, due to her veterinary medicine studies, will miss the upcoming Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast. Despite her disappointment, Muir prioritizes her education and looks forward to future Olympic appearances. She has set a potential target for the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir recently achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 1500 m at the World Athletics Championships, finishing fourth, and a sixth place in the 5,000 m event. She believes there is a lot of potential for future success, having competed in five races in 10 days.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old who went missing in December 2000, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party. A search began in a three-acre woodland area in Chapelizod, Dublin, beside the R112 near the River Liffey, involving excavations and expected to last several weeks. This year, six detectives reviewed his disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage from the night he vanished. The footage shows Deely talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland, where he worked, and later being followed by the same man on Haddington Road. Despite detectives releasing the footage in April and appealing for the man to come forward, he remains unidentified. Authorities have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

In the given passage, Argentine tennis player Juan Martin del Potro secures a victory against Stan Wawrinka, winning 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 and advancing in the tournament. Despite being ranked 165th due to injury issues, del Potro shows strong resilience and determination. He is now in the same half of the draw as Britain's Andy Murray and is set to play either France's 32nd seed Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young next. Del Potro expresses his happiness and gratitude towards the crowd and his renewed passion for the game after battling through multiple injuries.

In other tennis news, Australia's Nick Kyrgios is also in the same half of the draw as Murray and is on track to face him in the last 16. Kyrgios manages to come back from a two-set deficit to win against Germany's Dustin Brown in a thrilling, rain-affected match. The winner of the Kyrgios-Lopez match will then play either Murray or Australian John Millman in the last 16. Additionally, 10th seed

In 2017, Tunisia faced expulsion from the Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the organization, but an apology resolved the issue. Morocco was reinstated after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a participation ban. Both countries are looking forward to a positive future in African football. Tunisia's last complaint was regarding a contentious penalty decision in a match against Equatorial Guinea, but they never accused the referee or any CAF member of corruption. A meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou led to a reconciliation, allowing Tunisia to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup.

The passage provides a historical overview of the McLaren Formula 1 team, highlighting their past successes and recent decline. McLaren has won 182 grands prix and 12 drivers' world championships. The team's slump started in 2013 due to issues with chassis design and Honda power-unit problems. Despite recent challenges, the team still has two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton. McLaren's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with periods of domination in the 1980s and 1990s. Founder Bruce McLaren's death in 1970 did not halt the team's growth, and they won their first title in 1974. Ron Dennis took control of the team in the 1980s, leading to their first period of real domination. The team then experienced partnerships with Honda and Mercedes, and another period of success in the late 1990s with Mika Hakkinen. However, the wins have dried up since 2012, and the team is currently in a challenging phase. Ron Dennis believes that success will return, and the team

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where they found people still at the bar. Police discovered alcohol service had continued until 04:49 BST. The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with violating licensing hours. The judge, noting O'Neill's poor record, ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA three-point record, scoring 273 three-pointers in a single season as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry hit eight three-pointers in the game, while Klay Thompson scored 26 points to help the Warriors avoid their first three-game losing streak of the season. In another game, Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, leading the Chicago Bulls to a 89-78 win over the Miami Heat, significantly impacting Miami's playoff hopes.

Bas van Velzen, a YouTube star and free-kick specialist, tricked Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic by posing as a competition winner at Melwood. The players initially thought they were giving a dead-ball masterclass to a fan, but van Velzen impressed them with his exceptional free-kick skills. The experience was enjoyable for both the players and van Velzen, who later revealed his own famous T-shirt worn by Balotelli during Manchester City's 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

The passage discusses a study that found having an oophorectomy (removal of ovaries) can significantly reduce the risk of death for women diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the BRCA1 gene mutation, similar to Hollywood star Angelina Jolie who underwent the procedure. The study showed a 62% decrease in breast cancer death risk for women with a BRCA1 mutation who had an oophorectomy. However, this benefit was not observed in those with a BRCA2 mutation. The 20-year survival rate for the entire group of breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA genes was 77.4%. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

A couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, when an Amtrak train hit them as they were on the tracks. The incident occurred at around 10 am, involving the Carolinian train no. 80, which was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. No passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The couple was pronounced dead at the scene. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its route. It was suggested that the couple may have been living in a homeless camp, as a man who met them while collecting scrap metal shared that they appeared to be in difficult circumstances. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, Raleigh, and the trip from Charlotte to New York City usually takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. Despite helping the DEA carry out undercover stings around the world and aiding in the prosecution of drug lords and dictators, Toro is now facing deportation as he was never granted citizenship. He fears for his life if deported to Colombia and is currently living in the US illegally after retiring due to health issues. The DEA has refused to assist Toro with his citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits until he secures a green card or passport.

The passage discusses how the US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is looking into a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., that is using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge high fees from celebrities and companies aiming to protect their reputations. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies like YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have been targeted. ICANN is investigating whether the actions of Vox Populi are illegal. The company initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is now reconsidering after complaints from an advisory panel. Vox Populi charges $2,499 a year for the domain name, with most names sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year. The company claims its business is within the lines of ICANN rules and the law.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a pond. The case remained unsolved until DNA samples led police to the mother. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped as she explained the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. The mother faced potential charges of failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. Advances in DNA technology allowed the police to trace the mother through a match on the national database. The baby, found stillborn, was finally named Peter and re-buried in the churchyard. The investigation was solved using the latest techniques, and the case, which had been a mystery for decades, was closed.

A passenger, Kristopher Hicks, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi driven by Michael Young due to a misunderstanding. Young, a former soldier, had falsely believed Hicks intended to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank as a lesson. Hicks objected, leading to a nearly one-mile-long drive before he jumped out at over 20 mph. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, though the exact amount remains to be decided. Hicks now requires constant care from his mother and has developed epilepsy.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas due to several storms that brought reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, moving northeast and posing potential risks to communities but missing Wichita. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most dangerous and deadly, according to CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers. Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas and Potosi, Missouri, where wind damage, flooding, and hail were also reported. The storms affected not only Kansas but also other areas in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes, with more storms expected on Thursday.

In the upcoming middleweight clash in New Jersey, Luke Rockhold aims for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago, with a potential title shot on the line. Rockhold plans to use his mixed martial arts skills to dominate Lyoto Machida, who he believes has a limited chance of winning on his feet and no real chance on the ground. Machida, confident in his style and technique, hopes to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot as well. Both fighters acknowledge the mutual respect they have for each other but are determined to showcase their own styles and emerge victorious.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft touched down at Aero Acres Residential Airpark without its landing gear deployed, causing it to skid along the runway on its belly. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to re-engage the engines and take off back into the air, later flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The incident was captured in shocking footage, with the plane's propellers ricocheting off the ground and wings bouncing up and down from the impact. The most common cause of such gear-up landings is human error, where pilots forget to deploy the landing gear before touchdown, or mechanical faults, such as electric motor or hydraulic actuator failures. The FAA is investigating the incident.

In the passage, Manchester City's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, expresses disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure but pledges support for him until the end of the season. Despite underperforming, Toure will not be given a break, and Pellegrini emphasizes his importance to the team. Manchester City is currently facing a challenging period, with a struggling Premier League defense and questions about Pellegrini's future. Additionally, Sportsmail reported that the club is open to offers for Toure in the summer as they aim to revamp their aging squad. City goalkeeper Joe Hart supports Pellegrini and believes the players should take responsibility for their performances. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce warns Aaron Cresswell against making the same mistakes as other English players if he were to join Manchester City, amid interest from the club in signing the West Ham left-back.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the Godfather of Uxbridge, was set to be extradited to Italy but will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. In February, he lost his battle against extradition, but it emerged that his case expired in October and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore was first arrested on a European arrest warrant in 2013. He was never convicted of murder, but the Italian authorities wanted him returned to the country after he fled in 1995. Known as the Professor, Rancadore was tried in absentia and handed a seven-year prison term for his Mafia association. He was convicted for

In the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Paul Nicholls-trained Mr. Mole, Irish raider Special Tiara, and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his final day as a professional jockey's book of rides will not be finalized until Friday morning. Ironically, McCoy announced his intention to quit riding after winning at Newbury in February with Mr. Mole. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was murdered in 1975 by Jerome Sydney Barrett, who was convicted 33 years later. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the crime scene photos, and she declined for several decades. In 2015, she finally viewed the photos and expressed a desire for revenge. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, 150 yards from her home, with signs of strangulation and sexual assault. The case remained Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett's arrest in 2006, after his DNA matched that found on the victim's clothing. He was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.
